decision_content.verbatim_text: It is customary for the supplier to be given the right to conduct the defense of the claim to the extent this is practically feasible. The reason for this is that the supplier may think that the claim is frivolous or otherwise without merit or that the claim can be easily defended, whereas the purchasing party may simply wish to get itself out of the dispute by settling with the claimant.
decision_content.plain_text: It is customary for the supplier to have the right to conduct the defense of a claim, if feasible. This is because the supplier may believe the claim is without merit or easily defensible, while the purchasing party might prefer a quick settlement.
decision_content.expert_insight: This explains the common dynamic where the indemnitor (supplier) wants control over the defense to manage costs and strategy, while the indemnitee (Zebracorp) might prioritize quick resolution.
decision_content.justification: Explains the customary right of supplier to conduct defense.
decision_content.implication_company: Zebracorp should understand the supplier's motivation for wanting to control the defense, which is to manage costs and strategy, potentially avoiding settlements for claims they deem frivolous or easily defensible.
decision_content.implication_supplier: Supplier typically seeks control over the defense of a claim to manage strategy and costs, especially if they believe the claim is without merit or easily defensible, contrasting with a purchasing party's potential desire for a quick settlement.

decision_content.verbatim_text: However, it is important to remember that an indemnity is only as good as the creditworthiness of the party making the indemnity.
decision_content.plain_text: An indemnity's effectiveness is directly dependent on the indemnifying party's financial creditworthiness.
decision_content.expert_insight: This is a crucial practical consideration: even a perfectly drafted indemnity is worthless if the indemnitor cannot fulfill their financial obligations. Due diligence on supplier solvency is important.
decision_content.justification: Highlights a practical limitation of indemnities.
decision_content.implication_company: Zebracorp should consider the supplier's financial stability when relying on an indemnity.

decision_content.verbatim_text: “The [Supplier] will have no obligation to defend or indemnify Buyer under this [Clause] if and to the extent: i.) the [Purchaser] or any third party authorized by the [Purchaser] has altered the [Products] without the [Supplier]’s consent and the alleged infringement would not have occurred but for this alteration; ii.) the [Purchaser] or any third party authorized by the [Purchaser] has combined the [Products] with any other products or elements not furnished by the [Supplier] without the [Supplier]’s consent, and the alleged infringement would not have occurred but for this combination and the [Product] itself is not infringing; or iii.) the [Products] were designed or manufactured in accordance with the [Purchaser]’s written detailed design and specifications mandated by the [Purchaser] without freedom of design for the [Supplier] and the alleged infringement would not have occurred but for these written detailed designs and specifications”.
decision_content.plain_text: An example carve-out clause states that the Supplier has no indemnity obligation if: (i) the Purchaser or an authorized third party altered products without Supplier's consent, and the infringement wouldn't have occurred otherwise; (ii) the Purchaser or an authorized third party combined products with non-supplied elements without Supplier's consent, the infringement wouldn't have occurred otherwise, and the product itself isn't infringing; or (iii) products were designed to Purchaser's mandated specifications without Supplier's design freedom, and the infringement wouldn't have occurred otherwise.
decision_content.expert_insight: This example outlines typical carve-outs that shift liability back to the buyer for actions outside the supplier's control or design responsibility. The 'but for' causation is a key element for these exclusions.
decision_content.justification: Provides an example of a typical carve-out clause for IPR indemnity.
decision_content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs to be aware that its own actions (unauthorized modifications, combinations, or mandated designs) can negate supplier indemnity.
decision_content.implication_supplier: These carve-outs protect suppliers from liability when infringement is caused by the buyer's actions or specific instructions.
decision_content.source_insight: The text explicitly provides an example of a carve-out clause.

decision_content.verbatim_text: “This section contains i. the [Supplier]’s entire liability and all obligations related to third party intellectual property infringement or misappropriation, and ii. the [Purchaser]’s exclusive remedies against the [Supplier] for such third party intellectual property infringement or misappropriation. These remedies are provided in lieu of all other warranties, whether express, implied or statutory”.
decision_content.plain_text: An example clause for 'Entire Liability and Exclusive Remedies' states that the section defines the Supplier's entire liability and obligations for third-party IP infringement, and the Purchaser's exclusive remedies, replacing all other warranties.
decision_content.expert_insight: This type of clause aims to consolidate and limit the supplier's exposure to the specific terms of the IP indemnity section, excluding other potential claims or warranties. It's common in contracts to define the boundaries of liability.
decision_content.justification: Provides an example of an 'Entire Liability and Exclusive Remedies' clause.
decision_content.implication_company: Zebracorp's remedies for IP infringement will be limited to what is explicitly stated in the IP indemnity section.
decision_content.implication_supplier: This clause limits the supplier's overall liability for IP infringement to the negotiated terms of the indemnity section.
decision_content.source_insight: The text explicitly provides an example clause.

content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier] shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless [Zebracorp] and its Affiliates at its own expense from and against any claims, actions, liabilities, damages, costs and expenses (including but not limited to attorney's fees and costs) incurred by the [Zebracorp], its Affiliates or their respective customers and contractors as a result of infringement or alleged infringement of any intellectual property rights of any third parties by any [products and deliverable sold or licensed hereunder.”
content.plain_text: The Supplier must indemnify, defend, and hold harmless Zebracorp, its Affiliates, and their customers/contractors from any claims, actions, liabilities, damages, costs, and expenses (including attorney's fees) arising from infringement or alleged infringement of third-party intellectual property rights by the products/deliverables.
content.expert_insight: This is the core IPR indemnity clause, establishing the supplier's fundamental obligation to protect Zebracorp from IP infringement claims. It's critical for risk transfer in IT/Telco contracts.
content.conditions: Applies to products and deliverables sold or licensed under the agreement.
content.justification: This is the foundational obligation of the supplier, directly quoted as a typical IPR indemnity clause. It's a deal-breaker for Zebracorp's protection.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp has a right to be indemnified, defended, and held harmless against IP infringement claims, with costs covered by the supplier.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier has a mandatory obligation to indemnify, defend, and cover all related costs for Zebracorp against third-party IP infringement claims.
content.source_insight: The text provides this as an example of a typical IPR indemnity, indicating it's the desired standard.
content.text: The [Supplier] shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless [Zebracorp] and its Affiliates at its own expense from and against any claims, actions, liabilities, damages, costs and expenses (including but not limited to attorney's fees and costs) incurred by the [Zebracorp], its Affiliates or their respective customers and contractors as a result of infringement or alleged infringement of any intellectual property rights of any third parties by any [products and deliverable sold or licensed hereunder.”

content.verbatim_text: The scope of the indemnity should cover at the minimum patents, copyrights and trademarks. It is sufficient to refer to intellectual property rights in general or refer to the capitalized definition of Intellectual Property Rights, assuming the definition is broad enough. When agreeing to a specific list of the covered IPRs note in particular that patents are included in the list. Vendors will for obvious reasons seek to exclude patents from the scope of indemnity but such an exclusion should be categorically rejected.
content.plain_text: The IPR indemnity scope must, at a minimum, cover patents, copyrights, and trademarks. Zebracorp should ensure patents are explicitly included if a specific list is used, and must categorically reject any vendor attempts to exclude patents.
content.expert_insight: Patents are a major source of litigation in the IT/Telco industry. Excluding them would severely undermine the purpose of the indemnity, leaving Zebracorp exposed to significant risk.
content.conditions: Applies when defining the scope of IPRs covered by the indemnity.
content.justification: The text explicitly states 'categorically rejected' for patent exclusion, highlighting its critical importance due to high litigation risk in the industry.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp gains comprehensive protection across key IP types, especially patents, which are high-risk areas.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's indemnity obligation will extend to patents, copyrights, and trademarks, increasing their potential liability.
content.source_insight: The text emphasizes the high frequency of patent infringement claims in the IT/Telco industry as the reason for this strict stance.
content.text: The scope of the indemnity should cover at the minimum patents, copyrights and trademarks. It is sufficient to refer to intellectual property rights in general or refer to the capitalized definition of Intellectual Property Rights, assuming the definition is broad enough. When agreeing to a specific list of the covered IPRs note in particular that patents are included in the list. Vendors will for obvious reasons seek to exclude patents from the scope of indemnity but such an exclusion should be categorically rejected.

content.verbatim_text: The indemnitees should include the contracting entity of Zebracorp and its Affiliates, as applicable. ... It is not necessary to mention our customers and contractors as the indemnitees (i.e. the beneficiaries of the indemnity) if it is otherwise clear from the context that the indemnity also covers damages incurred by such customers/contractors of Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: The indemnity must explicitly name Zebracorp and its Affiliates as indemnitees. It is not strictly necessary to name customers and contractors if the context clearly extends coverage to damages they incur.
content.expert_insight: Ensuring affiliates are covered is crucial for Zebracorp's global operations and distribution models. Clarity on customer/contractor coverage prevents disputes over the scope of protection.
content.conditions: Applies when drafting the indemnitee clause.
content.justification: The text uses 'should include' and 'required to be mentioned' for Affiliates, indicating high importance. For customers/contractors, it offers flexibility based on context, making it High rather than Critical.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp and its Affiliates are directly protected. Potential for customers/contractors to also be covered, reducing Zebracorp's indirect liability.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's indemnity obligation extends to Zebracorp's Affiliates and potentially its customers/contractors.
content.source_insight: The rationale for including Affiliates is explained by their potential involvement in ordering or distribution.
content.text: The indemnitees should include the contracting entity of Zebracorp and its Affiliates, as applicable. ... It is not necessary to mention our customers and contractors as the indemnitees (i.e. the beneficiaries of the indemnity) if it is otherwise clear from the context that the indemnity also covers damages incurred by such customers/contractors of Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: Most vendors will seek to limit the obligation to compensate attorneys/legal fees to reasonable fees only. Whilst this may be seem a reasonable proposition, it should not be readily accepted. Attorneys/legal fees can be substantial, and having an obligation to prove that these fees are reasonable can materially impair our ability to seek compensation for such costs. Instead of agreeing to ‘reasonable attorneys fees’, we should consider countering with in e.g. ‘necessarily incurred attorneys fees’. As a fallback we can agree to inserting a ‘reasonable’ qualifier.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must not readily accept limitations on attorney/legal fees to 'reasonable fees only'. Instead, Zebracorp should counter with 'necessarily incurred attorneys fees'. A 'reasonable' qualifier can be a fallback.
content.expert_insight: Legal fees in IP litigation are notoriously high. Proving 'reasonableness' adds a significant burden and risk of under-recovery for Zebracorp. 'Necessarily incurred' is a better standard.
content.conditions: Applies during negotiation of legal fee compensation.
content.justification: The text explicitly states 'should not be readily accepted' and explains the material impairment to Zebracorp's ability to seek compensation, indicating a critical risk.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp protects its ability to recover full legal costs without the burden of proving 'reasonableness'.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's liability for legal fees will be broader, covering 'necessarily incurred' costs rather than just 'reasonable' ones.
content.source_insight: The text highlights the substantial nature of legal fees and the difficulty in proving their reasonableness.
content.text: Most vendors will seek to limit the obligation to compensate attorneys/legal fees to reasonable fees only. Whilst this may be seem a reasonable proposition, it should not be readily accepted. Attorneys/legal fees can be substantial, and having an obligation to prove that these fees are reasonable can materially impair our ability to seek compensation for such costs. Instead of agreeing to ‘reasonable attorneys fees’, we should consider countering with in e.g. ‘necessarily incurred attorneys fees’. As a fallback we can agree to inserting a ‘reasonable’ qualifier.

content.verbatim_text: A number of vendors will seek to limit the indemnity to damages that are ‘finally awarded’ by in e.g. saying that they will indemnify against any “damages finally awarded by a court of competent jurisdiction against [Zebracorp]”. This qualifier changes the scope of the indemnity dramatically as it limits the indemnity solely to those damages that a court would order Zebracorp to pay to the third party claimant. Essentially the claim would not only have to be made by the third party claimant but subsequently litigated, and the judgment must be final before the vendor would incur any obligation to compensate us for the damages we have incurred. This leaves a substantial amount of damages and costs out of the indemnity and is only rarely acceptable.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must rarely accept indemnity clauses that limit coverage to 'finally awarded damages'. This significantly restricts the scope and leaves Zebracorp exposed to substantial unrecoverable costs.
content.expert_insight: Most IP disputes settle before a final court award. This limitation would effectively nullify much of the indemnity's value, leaving Zebracorp to bear settlement costs, business disruption, and other damages.
content.conditions: Applies during negotiation of the scope of damages covered by the indemnity.
content.justification: The text states this 'changes the scope of the indemnity dramatically' and is 'only rarely acceptable', indicating a critical impact on Zebracorp's protection.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp avoids bearing significant costs (e.g., settlement, business disruption) that would be excluded by a 'finally awarded' limitation.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's liability remains broad, covering damages beyond just those 'finally awarded' by a court.
content.source_insight: The text explains that most IP lawsuits settle and Zebracorp incurs various costs beyond court-ordered damages.
content.text: A number of vendors will seek to limit the indemnity to damages that are ‘finally awarded’ by in e.g. saying that they will indemnify against any “damages finally awarded by a court of competent jurisdiction against [Zebracorp]”. This qualifier changes the scope of the indemnity dramatically as it limits the indemnity solely to those damages that a court would order Zebracorp to pay to the third party claimant. Essentially the claim would not only have to be made by the third party claimant but subsequently litigated, and the judgment must be final before the vendor would incur any obligation to compensate us for the damages we have incurred. This leaves a substantial amount of damages and costs out of the indemnity and is only rarely acceptable.

content.verbatim_text: If we do exceptionally agree to limit the indemnity to finally awarded damages we should specify that this final award can be either through arbitration or local court and that the supplier will also pay for any sums agreed in a settlement. Also we should insert a provision to specify the supplier’s obligations and liability in the event there is an injunction (i.e. a court order prohibiting ZEBRACORP or its customers from using or distributing the allegedly infringing products/services).
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp exceptionally agrees to limit indemnity to 'finally awarded damages', it must ensure the definition includes arbitration awards and settlement sums. Additionally, a provision for supplier obligations/liability in case of an injunction must be included.
content.expert_insight: These are crucial safeguards if Zebracorp is forced to accept a 'finally awarded' limitation, ensuring some recovery for common dispute resolutions and addressing the severe impact of injunctions.
content.conditions: Only applies if Zebracorp 'exceptionally agrees' to limit indemnity to 'finally awarded damages'.
content.justification: This is a conditional guideline for a 'rarely acceptable' scenario, making it High. It provides essential mitigation if the primary critical guideline cannot be met.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp gains some protection for arbitration and settlement outcomes, and clarity on supplier's role during injunctions, even with a limited indemnity.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's liability, even if limited to 'finally awarded damages', would still encompass arbitration awards, settlement sums, and specific obligations during injunctions.
content.source_insight: The text emphasizes the need to cover settlements and injunctions due to their common occurrence and significant impact.
content.text: If we do exceptionally agree to limit the indemnity to finally awarded damages we should specify that this final award can be either through arbitration or local court and that the supplier will also pay for any sums agreed in a settlement. Also we should insert a provision to specify the supplier’s obligations and liability in the event there is an injunction (i.e. a court order prohibiting ZEBRACORP or its customers from using or distributing the allegedly infringing products/services).

content.verbatim_text: The indemnity should apply to claims made in any country/jurisdiction in the world. However, it may be acceptable to agree that the indemnity will not apply in countries that do not provide adequate protection of intellectual property rights. This can be accomplished in e.g. by saying that the indemnity will not apply to claims made in countries that are not parties to the Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property. Any other geographic limitations should be carefully reviewed and discussed with Legal & Compliance.
content.plain_text: The indemnity should ideally cover claims globally. Zebracorp may accept exclusions for countries without adequate IP protection (e.g., non-Paris Convention members). Any other geographic limitations require careful review and Legal & Compliance consultation.
content.expert_insight: Global coverage is essential for Zebracorp's international operations. Strategic exclusions for 'IP-weak' countries can be a reasonable compromise, but broad exclusions are unacceptable.
content.conditions: Applies during negotiation of the geographic scope of the indemnity.
content.justification: The text uses 'should apply' for global coverage and 'may be acceptable' for specific exclusions, indicating a strong preference but some flexibility. 'Carefully reviewed' suggests high importance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp secures broad geographic protection, with a potential for limited, justifiable exclusions.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's indemnity obligation will generally be global, with potential for specific, agreed-upon geographic carve-outs.
content.source_insight: The text provides an example of a justifiable geographic limitation (non-Paris Convention countries).
content.text: The indemnity should apply to claims made in any country/jurisdiction in the world. However, it may be acceptable to agree that the indemnity will not apply in countries that do not provide adequate protection of intellectual property rights. This can be accomplished in e.g. by saying that the indemnity will not apply to claims made in countries that are not parties to the Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property. Any other geographic limitations should be carefully reviewed and discussed with Legal & Compliance.

content.verbatim_text: Vendors are likely to request to delete the words “alleged infringement” from the scope of the indemnity and merely refer to “infringement of third party intellectual property rights”. The deletion of word “alleged” can be accepted if it is otherwise clear from the context that any infringement claim alone will trigger the indemnity.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can accept the deletion of 'alleged infringement' if the contract context clearly indicates that an infringement claim alone triggers the indemnity.
content.expert_insight: This is a minor point of drafting. The key is ensuring that the indemnity is triggered by a claim, not just a proven infringement, to provide early protection.
content.conditions: Only if the context clearly ensures that an infringement claim alone triggers the indemnity.
content.justification: The text states 'can be accepted' under a specific condition, indicating it's a negotiable point of medium importance, as long as the underlying protection remains.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains protection against claims, even if the word 'alleged' is removed, provided the trigger mechanism is clear.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's obligation is triggered by a claim, regardless of the 'alleged' wording, if the context is clear.
content.source_insight: The text clarifies that the intent is for the indemnity to be triggered by the claim itself.
content.text: Vendors are likely to request to delete the words “alleged infringement” from the scope of the indemnity and merely refer to “infringement of third party intellectual property rights”. The deletion of word “alleged” can be accepted if it is otherwise clear from the context that any infringement claim alone will trigger the indemnity.

content.verbatim_text: The term “indemnify” and the term “hold harmless” are fairly similar to each other. Accordingly, we should be able to agree to delete the words “and hold harmless” from the indemnity provision as long as we retain the words “shall indemnify”. However, it is not recommended to delete the word “indemnify” and leave the term “hold harmless”. This is because in some countries, the term “hold harmless” does not have a well established legal meaning.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can agree to delete 'and hold harmless' if 'shall indemnify' is retained. However, Zebracorp must not delete 'indemnify' and only retain 'hold harmless' due to potential legal ambiguity in some jurisdictions.
content.expert_insight: While often used together, 'indemnify' is the legally stronger and more universally understood term for financial protection. Retaining it ensures clarity and enforceability.
content.conditions: Applies during drafting/negotiation of the indemnity clause wording.
content.justification: The text states 'should be able to agree' for deletion of 'hold harmless' but 'not recommended' for deleting 'indemnify', indicating a medium importance for the specific wording, with a clear prohibition for the less robust term.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp ensures the indemnity remains legally robust and enforceable by retaining the term 'indemnify'.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's core obligation remains clear and legally sound.
content.source_insight: The text highlights the legal ambiguity of 'hold harmless' in some countries.
content.text: The term “indemnify” and the term “hold harmless” are fairly similar to each other. Accordingly, we should be able to agree to delete the words “and hold harmless” from the indemnity provision as long as we retain the words “shall indemnify”. However, it is not recommended to delete the word “indemnify” and leave the term “hold harmless”. This is because in some countries, the term “hold harmless” does not have a well established legal meaning.

content.verbatim_text: However, we should be cautious to accept wording where we agree that the products must directly infringe third party intellectual property rights. This addition would imply that the product must itself infringe at the moment of delivery and would remove the supplier’s liability for any claims that are caused by the combination of the supplier product to our product.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must be cautious and generally avoid accepting wording that limits indemnity to 'directly infringe' third-party IP rights, as this would exclude liability for combination claims.
content.expert_insight: Combination claims are common in complex IT environments. Limiting 'direct infringement' would create a significant loophole, shifting substantial risk to Zebracorp.
content.conditions: Applies during negotiation of the definition of infringement.
content.justification: The text uses 'should be cautious to accept' and explains that it 'would remove the supplier’s liability for any claims that are caused by the combination', indicating a critical impact on Zebracorp's protection.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp avoids assuming liability for combination claims, which are a common source of IP disputes.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier remains liable for claims arising from the combination of its products with Zebracorp's, not just direct infringement.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly links this wording to the exclusion of combination claims.
content.text: However, we should be cautious to accept wording where we agree that the products must directly infringe third party intellectual property rights. This addition would imply that the product must itself infringe at the moment of delivery and would remove the supplier’s liability for any claims that are caused by the combination of the supplier product to our product.

content.verbatim_text: Sophisticated vendors may attempt to limit their liability to reasonable royalties that are based upon revenue derived by the vendor from Zebracorp from sales or license of the infringing product. By making such limitation the vendor would attempt to confine its liability to the royalty payable for the number of infringing products sold by it to Zebracorp. This is generally not acceptable as this type of a limitation would rule out the vendor’s liability for any royalties that our end customer ends up paying to the third party claimant. It would also exclude the vendor’s liability for any royalties that are calculated on a per use basis or calculated in e.g. by the revenues made by the end user.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must generally not accept limitations on supplier liability to royalties based solely on the vendor's revenue from Zebracorp, as this excludes royalties paid by end customers or calculated on a per-use/end-user revenue basis.
content.expert_insight: This limitation drastically reduces the supplier's exposure, leaving Zebracorp (and its customers) to bear the brunt of actual damages, which are often tied to end-user value or usage, not just the component's sale price to Zebracorp.
content.conditions: Applies during negotiation of liability caps or royalty calculations.
content.justification: The text states 'generally not acceptable' and explains how it 'would rule out the vendor’s liability' for significant damages, indicating a critical impact on Zebracorp's recovery.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp ensures the supplier's liability covers the full scope of damages, including those related to end-customer use and revenue.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's liability for royalties will be based on the broader impact of the infringement, not just its direct revenue from Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text highlights the substantial difference between the value of a component and the value of the Zebracorp system incorporating it.
content.text: Sophisticated vendors may attempt to limit their liability to reasonable royalties that are based upon revenue derived by the vendor from Zebracorp from sales or license of the infringing product. By making such limitation the vendor would attempt to confine its liability to the royalty payable for the number of infringing products sold by it to Zebracorp. This is generally not acceptable as this type of a limitation would rule out the vendor’s liability for any royalties that our end customer ends up paying to the third party claimant. It would also exclude the vendor’s liability for any royalties that are calculated on a per use basis or calculated in e.g. by the revenues made by the end user.

content.verbatim_text: In the event this request to exclude per-use royalties from the scope of the indemnity cannot be negotiated away, it is often preferable to agree to a monetary liability cap instead of agreeing to such request.
content.plain_text: If the exclusion of per-use royalties cannot be negotiated away, Zebracorp should prefer agreeing to a monetary liability cap instead.
content.expert_insight: This is a strategic fallback. A monetary cap, while not ideal, is often more predictable and less damaging than an exclusion that could leave Zebracorp fully exposed to uncapped, potentially massive, per-use royalty claims.
content.conditions: If the supplier's request to exclude per-use royalties cannot be negotiated away.
content.justification: This is a strong recommendation ('often preferable') for a fallback position when a critical point cannot be achieved, making it High.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp mitigates the risk of uncapped per-use royalty liability by opting for a defined monetary cap.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's liability for per-use royalties would be capped, providing some predictability.
content.source_insight: The text offers a pragmatic alternative when a preferred position is unattainable.
content.text: In the event this request to exclude per-use royalties from the scope of the indemnity cannot be negotiated away, it is often preferable to agree to a monetary liability cap instead of agreeing to such request.

content.verbatim_text: We should be careful in granting the supplier’s a right to defend the claim. ... This means that we should not offer the supplier unconditional and sole right and authority to defend the claims. Further, in those rare occasions where the supplier’s liability for IPR is capped or limtied, we obviously cannot allow the supplier to freely defend the case.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must be careful in granting the supplier the right to defend claims and must not offer the supplier an unconditional and sole right to defend. If the supplier's IPR liability is capped, Zebracorp cannot allow the supplier to freely defend the case.
content.expert_insight: Granting sole defense rights can lead to conflicts of interest, especially if Zebracorp's customers are involved or if the supplier's liability is capped. Zebracorp needs to retain control or significant influence.
content.conditions: Applies when negotiating the supplier's right to defend claims.
content.justification: The text uses 'should not offer' and 'obviously cannot allow', indicating a strong prohibition due to potential adverse impacts on Zebracorp's interests and control.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains control or influence over the defense strategy, protecting its business interests and customer relationships.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's right to defend claims will be conditional and not sole, especially if its liability is capped.
content.source_insight: The text explains that Zebracorp's customers are often targets, and claims may involve multiple vendors, making sole defense by one supplier problematic.
content.text: We should be careful in granting the supplier’s a right to defend the claim. ... This means that we should not offer the supplier unconditional and sole right and authority to defend the claims. Further, in those rare occasions where the supplier’s liability for IPR is capped or limtied, we obviously cannot allow the supplier to freely defend the case.

content.verbatim_text: However, the suppliers are likely to wish to introduce a third option, which effectively gives the supplier the right to require the return of the infringing products by agreeing to refund us the purchase price paid for the product, less a reasonable charge for depreciation and/or prior use. We should be careful when agreeing to accept this type of refund. In direct procurement contracts ZEBRACORP is likely to have sold and distributed the infringing products further to our end customers, and returning the products or requiring the end customer to cease further use of the product may cause irreparable damage and costs that far exceeds the potential royalties payable for the alleged infringement, or in worst case it may be impossible to comply with such request. Instead of agreeing to return the products or cease further use of the products, we should in such cases offer to agree to cease all further distribution and resale of the infringing products.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must be careful when accepting a supplier's option to require return of infringing products for a refund. Instead, Zebracorp should offer to cease further distribution and resale of the infringing products.
content.expert_insight: Returning products or forcing end-customers to cease use can cause severe business disruption and reputational damage for Zebracorp, far exceeding the value of the refund. Ceasing future distribution is a more manageable compromise.
content.conditions: Applies when negotiating ancillary obligations/options for the supplier in case of infringement.
content.justification: The text uses 'should be careful' and explains the 'irreparable damage and costs' this option could cause, indicating a high risk. It then provides a strong alternative ('should in such cases offer').
content.implication_company: Zebracorp avoids significant business disruption and customer dissatisfaction by not being forced to recall products from end-users.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's options for resolving infringement are limited, preventing them from forcing product returns from Zebracorp's customers.
content.source_insight: The text highlights the potential for irreparable damage and costs to Zebracorp's business operations and customer relationships.
content.text: However, the suppliers are likely to wish to introduce a third option, which effectively gives the supplier the right to require the return of the infringing products by agreeing to refund us the purchase price paid for the product, less a reasonable charge for depreciation and/or prior use. We should be careful when agreeing to accept this type of refund. In direct procurement contracts ZEBRACORP is likely to have sold and distributed the infringing products further to our end customers, and returning the products or requiring the end customer to cease further use of the product may cause irreparable damage and costs that far exceeds the potential royalties payable for the alleged infringement, or in worst case it may be impossible to comply with such request. Instead of agreeing to return the products or cease further use of the products, we should in such cases offer to agree to cease all further distribution and resale of the infringing products.

content.verbatim_text: When agreeing to this third option, we should also add language saying that this refund/right to cease further distribution of products is only available to the supplier in the event the two first options (i.e. the Design-Around and Substitution) are not reasonably feasible or achievable, and provided that we are given reasonable time to cease such further distribution. It is also recommended to include the following: “[Supplier] shall at all times act in such a way as to minimise interruption and disruption to the business operations of [ZEBRACORP] and its customers and contractors.” or substantially similar language to protect Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp agrees to the 'cease distribution' option, it must be conditional on Design-Around and Substitution not being feasible, and Zebracorp must be given reasonable time to comply. Additionally, language requiring the supplier to minimize business interruption for Zebracorp and its customers should be included.
content.expert_insight: These conditions protect Zebracorp from being forced into a disruptive option prematurely and ensure the supplier acts responsibly to mitigate Zebracorp's business impact.
content.conditions: If Zebracorp agrees to the supplier's option to cease further distribution of infringing products.
content.justification: These are crucial conditions to mitigate the impact of a less preferred option, making them High importance for Zebracorp's protection.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp ensures that less disruptive options are prioritized and that its business operations are protected during the resolution process.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's ability to exercise the 'cease distribution' option is restricted and comes with an obligation to minimize disruption to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text provides specific drafting recommendations to protect Zebracorp's interests.
content.text: When agreeing to this third option, we should also add language saying that this refund/right to cease further distribution of products is only available to the supplier in the event the two first options (i.e. the Design-Around and Substitution) are not reasonably feasible or achievable, and provided that we are given reasonable time to cease such further distribution. It is also recommended to include the following: “[Supplier] shall at all times act in such a way as to minimise interruption and disruption to the business operations of [ZEBRACORP] and its customers and contractors.” or substantially similar language to protect Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: It is important to mention that the supplier is not relieved from its obligation to indemnify Zebracorp by simply picking one of the above three options. This is because Zebracorp is likely to have already incurred damages and costs even if the supplier proves successful in implementing in e.g. a design-around that removes the infringement. This is achieved by including the word: “…without prejudice to its indemnity obligation…” in the above example provision.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must ensure that the supplier's exercise of any ancillary options (Design-Around, Substitution, or Cease Distribution) does not relieve the supplier of its primary indemnity obligation. This is achieved by including 'without prejudice to its indemnity obligation' in the clause.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical point. Ancillary options address future use, but Zebracorp will have already incurred costs (legal fees, business disruption) from the infringement claim itself. The indemnity must cover these past damages.
content.conditions: Applies when drafting the ancillary options clause.
content.justification: The text states 'It is important to mention' and explains the critical reason why the indemnity obligation must remain, making it a CRITICAL guideline.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp ensures it can recover all incurred damages and costs, even if the supplier successfully implements a resolution option.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's indemnity obligation is separate and continues even after exercising ancillary options.
content.source_insight: The text clarifies that damages are incurred even before a resolution option is implemented.
content.text: It is important to mention that the supplier is not relieved from its obligation to indemnify Zebracorp by simply picking one of the above three options. This is because Zebracorp is likely to have already incurred damages and costs even if the supplier proves successful in implementing in e.g. a design-around that removes the infringement. This is achieved by including the word: “…without prejudice to its indemnity obligation…” in the above example provision.

content.verbatim_text: Care should be taken when agreeing to notify the supplier of the infringement claim. Ideally we should undertake to inform the supplier of the claim “within a reasonable time period”. If this is rejected by the supplier, we could agree to inform “without any undue delay”. However, we should not agree to wording such as “immediately” or “promptly” as any inadvertent delay may give the supplier a case for trying to walk away from the entire indemnity obligation.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should agree to notify the supplier of infringement claims 'within a reasonable time period' or, as a fallback, 'without any undue delay'. Zebracorp must not agree to 'immediately' or 'promptly' to avoid inadvertently voiding the indemnity.
content.expert_insight: Strict notification clauses (e.g., 'immediately') are traps that can allow suppliers to escape liability on technicalities. 'Reasonable time' or 'without undue delay' provides necessary flexibility for Zebracorp.
content.conditions: Applies when negotiating Zebracorp's notification obligations.
content.justification: The text uses 'should not agree' and explains the severe consequence ('walk away from the entire indemnity obligation'), making it a High priority to protect Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp protects its right to indemnity by having a flexible and realistic notification period.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier receives timely notification but cannot use minor delays as an excuse to avoid indemnity.
content.source_insight: The text highlights the risk of inadvertent delays and their potential impact on the indemnity obligation.
content.text: Care should be taken when agreeing to notify the supplier of the infringement claim. Ideally we should undertake to inform the supplier of the claim “within a reasonable time period”. If this is rejected by the supplier, we could agree to inform “without any undue delay”. However, we should not agree to wording such as “immediately” or “promptly” as any inadvertent delay may give the supplier a case for trying to walk away from the entire indemnity obligation.

content.verbatim_text: In the event the supplier is adamant about using the words “promptly” or “immediately”, we should consider adding in e.g. the following clarifying language: “failure by the [buyer] to inform the [supplier] of any claim in a timely manner will only affect the obligations of the [supplier] if and to the extent the [supplier] is directly prejudiced as a result of such delay”.
content.plain_text: If the supplier insists on 'promptly' or 'immediately' for notification, Zebracorp should add clarifying language stating that failure to notify only affects supplier obligations if the supplier is directly prejudiced by the delay.
content.expert_insight: This 'no prejudice' clause is a critical safeguard, preventing the supplier from using a technical breach of notification as an automatic escape from indemnity, requiring them to prove actual harm.
content.conditions: If the supplier insists on 'promptly' or 'immediately' for notification.
content.justification: This is a strong recommendation ('should consider adding') for a fallback position to mitigate a high risk, making it High.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp protects its indemnity rights by ensuring minor notification delays do not automatically void the supplier's obligations.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier must demonstrate actual prejudice from a notification delay to reduce or avoid its indemnity obligations.
content.source_insight: The text provides specific language to mitigate the risk of strict notification clauses.
content.text: In the event the supplier is adamant about using the words “promptly” or “immediately”, we should consider adding in e.g. the following clarifying language: “failure by the [buyer] to inform the [supplier] of any claim in a timely manner will only affect the obligations of the [supplier] if and to the extent the [supplier] is directly prejudiced as a result of such delay”.

content.verbatim_text: Note however that we should not allow the supplier to take control over the defense/settlement of the claim in the event we agree to cap the supplier’s liability for the claims. Please consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team on how to revise the indemnity and defense provisions in such case.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must not allow the supplier to control the defense or settlement of a claim if the supplier's liability for that claim is capped. Legal & Compliance must be consulted for revisions in such cases.
content.expert_insight: If the supplier's liability is capped, their incentive to vigorously defend or achieve the best settlement for Zebracorp diminishes. Zebracorp must retain control to protect its uncapped exposure.
content.conditions: If the supplier's liability for IPR claims is capped.
content.justification: The text uses 'should not allow' and highlights the critical conflict of interest when liability is capped, making this a CRITICAL prohibition.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains control over defense and settlement when its exposure is uncapped, preventing the supplier from making decisions that could adversely affect Zebracorp.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's right to control defense/settlement is removed or limited if its liability is capped.
content.source_insight: The text implicitly warns against the conflict of interest when the indemnitor's financial exposure is limited.
content.text: Note however that we should not allow the supplier to take control over the defense/settlement of the claim in the event we agree to cap the supplier’s liability for the claims. Please consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team on how to revise the indemnity and defense provisions in such case.

content.verbatim_text: ZEBRACORP’s duty to cooperate in defending the claim should be subject to such cooperation being reasonable. We would also expect to be compensated for the costs that we incur from providing such assistance. If this point becomes contentious, we can agree to cooperate and assist at our own cost so long as our cooperation obligation is limited to whatever is ‘reasonably’ required by the supplier.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's duty to cooperate in defense must be reasonable, and Zebracorp should expect compensation for its assistance costs. If contentious, Zebracorp can agree to cooperate at its own cost, provided the obligation is limited to what is 'reasonably' required.
content.expert_insight: Zebracorp's resources should not be unduly burdened by the supplier's defense. Compensation for assistance is fair, and limiting the obligation to 'reasonable' requests prevents overreach.
content.conditions: Applies when negotiating Zebracorp's duty to cooperate in defense.
content.justification: The text uses 'should be subject to' and 'would also expect', indicating a strong preference. The fallback position is also clearly defined, making it High.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's cooperation is limited to reasonable requests, and it seeks compensation for its efforts, protecting its resources.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier can expect reasonable cooperation from Zebracorp, but may need to compensate Zebracorp for its assistance.
content.source_insight: The text balances the need for cooperation with the protection of Zebracorp's resources.
content.text: ZEBRACORP’s duty to cooperate in defending the claim should be subject to such cooperation being reasonable. We would also expect to be compensated for the costs that we incur from providing such assistance. If this point becomes contentious, we can agree to cooperate and assist at our own cost so long as our cooperation obligation is limited to whatever is ‘reasonably’ required by the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: The Supplier may also require that Zebracorp (as the party benefiting from indemnity) will refrain from admitting liability in third party claims and will refrain from settling such claim without the supplier’s express prior written consent. This is generally acceptable.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can generally accept requirements to refrain from admitting liability or settling third-party claims without the supplier's prior written consent.
content.expert_insight: This is a standard and reasonable request from an indemnitor, as Zebracorp's actions could prejudice the supplier's defense or increase their liability.
content.conditions: Applies when negotiating Zebracorp's actions regarding third-party claims.
content.justification: The text states 'This is generally acceptable', indicating a common and non-contentious point of medium importance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must coordinate with the supplier on admissions of liability and settlements.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier gains control over Zebracorp's actions that could impact the claim.
content.source_insight: This is a common procedural requirement in indemnity clauses.
content.text: The Supplier may also require that Zebracorp (as the party benefiting from indemnity) will refrain from admitting liability in third party claims and will refrain from settling such claim without the supplier’s express prior written consent. This is generally acceptable.

content.verbatim_text: Care should be taken in negotiating these carve-outs. In each case it is worth mentioning specifically that the supplier will not benefit from the exclusion if the infringement would not have occurred without the modification or combination made by buyer or without buyer specification. As regards to unauthorized modifications or combinations, we should try to include language that shifts the liability back to the supplier in cases where the supplier has separately given its consent to the modification or combination even if the modification or combination was not authorized in the products specifications. This can be done by adding the words ‘without supplier’s consent’ in the above example.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must carefully negotiate carve-outs. For unauthorized modifications or combinations, Zebracorp should ensure the supplier remains liable if the infringement would have occurred regardless, or if the supplier consented to the modification/combination.
content.expert_insight: These nuances prevent suppliers from using carve-outs to escape liability for infringements that are not truly caused by Zebracorp's actions or for which they implicitly approved.
content.conditions: Applies when negotiating carve-outs for supplier liability.
content.justification: The text uses 'Care should be taken' and 'should try to include language', indicating a high importance for protecting Zebracorp against overly broad exclusions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp avoids liability for infringements where its actions were not the sole cause or were implicitly approved by the supplier.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's ability to use carve-outs for modifications/combinations is limited, requiring a direct causal link or absence of consent.
content.source_insight: The text provides specific drafting advice ('without supplier’s consent') to achieve this protection.
content.text: Care should be taken in negotiating these carve-outs. In each case it is worth mentioning specifically that the supplier will not benefit from the exclusion if the infringement would not have occurred without the modification or combination made by buyer or without buyer specification. As regards to unauthorized modifications or combinations, we should try to include language that shifts the liability back to the supplier in cases where the supplier has separately given its consent to the modification or combination even if the modification or combination was not authorized in the products specifications. This can be done by adding the words ‘without supplier’s consent’ in the above example.

content.verbatim_text: As for the carve-out on Zebracorp provided specifications, it is important to stress that the specifications have to be mandated by Zebracorp without any freedom of design for the supplier in order for the supplier to be able to shift the liability for IP infringement to Zebracorp. In most cases, Zebracorp will have to rely on the expertise of the supplier in building and designing the product, and the mere fact that Zebracorp provides certain requirements/specifications for the products it purchases should not transfer the risk of IP infringements over to Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: For carve-outs based on Zebracorp's specifications, Zebracorp must ensure the supplier can only shift liability if the specifications were mandated without any design freedom for the supplier. Providing general requirements should not transfer IP infringement risk to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: Suppliers often try to shift IP risk if Zebracorp provides any input. This guideline ensures that the supplier, as the expert, retains IP liability unless Zebracorp dictates a design so precisely that the supplier has no discretion.
content.conditions: Applies when negotiating carve-outs related to buyer specifications.
content.justification: The text states 'it is important to stress' and explains the rationale for not transferring risk, indicating a high importance for Zebracorp's protection.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp avoids assuming IP infringement liability for products designed by the supplier, even if Zebracorp provided specifications, unless those specifications were highly prescriptive.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier retains IP liability for products designed based on Zebracorp's specifications, unless Zebracorp mandated the design without any supplier freedom.
content.source_insight: The text emphasizes Zebracorp's reliance on supplier expertise.
content.text: As for the carve-out on Zebracorp provided specifications, it is important to stress that the specifications have to be mandated by Zebracorp without any freedom of design for the supplier in order for the supplier to be able to shift the liability for IP infringement to Zebracorp. In most cases, Zebracorp will have to rely on the expertise of the supplier in building and designing the product, and the mere fact that Zebracorp provides certain requirements/specifications for the products it purchases should not transfer the risk of IP infringements over to Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: Another common carve-out proposed by sophisticated vendors seeks to exclude ‘all claims asserted by a company, which exercises control over Zebracorp or which is controlled by Zebracorp’. This carve out essentially prevents Zebracorp from taking advantage of the indemnity when the third party making the infringement claim is in fact not a third party but an affiliated company of Zebracorp. Such carve-outs are generally acceptable.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can generally accept carve-outs that exclude claims asserted by its affiliated companies (i.e., companies controlling or controlled by Zebracorp).
content.expert_insight: This is a reasonable exclusion, as indemnities are typically for third-party claims, not internal disputes within a corporate group.
content.conditions: Applies when negotiating carve-outs for claims from affiliated companies.
content.justification: The text states 'Such carve-outs are generally acceptable', indicating a common and non-contentious point of medium importance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp cannot use the indemnity for claims from its own affiliates, which is a standard commercial practice.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier is protected from indemnity claims originating from Zebracorp's corporate group.
content.source_insight: The text clarifies that such claims are not truly 'third-party' claims.
content.text: Another common carve-out proposed by sophisticated vendors seeks to exclude ‘all claims asserted by a company, which exercises control over Zebracorp or which is controlled by Zebracorp’. This carve out essentially prevents Zebracorp from taking advantage of the indemnity when the third party making the infringement claim is in fact not a third party but an affiliated company of Zebracorp. Such carve-outs are generally acceptable.

content.verbatim_text: The suppliers are fairly often likely to represent the viewpoint that Zebracorp should itself indemnify the supplier for any claims that are based on these carve-outs i.e. based on Zebracorp modifications etc. Such indemnities from Zebracorp to supplier should not be taken for granted. We should keep in mind that Zebracorp is not providing any products/services to the supplier against a fee and accordingly should not be expected to provide indemnities to the supplier. The indemnities should be provided by the selling party to the purchasing party. ... Instead of agreeing to indemnity the supplier for all costs and damages, we should seek to only agree to defend the supplier against the third party claim.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should not take for granted requests to indemnify the supplier for claims based on carve-outs (e.g., Zebracorp's modifications). Zebracorp should generally resist providing indemnities to the supplier. If an indemnity is considered, Zebracorp should seek to only agree to defend the supplier against the third-party claim, not indemnify for all costs and damages.
content.expert_insight: Indemnities typically flow from seller to buyer. Zebracorp should avoid becoming an indemnitor unless it's acting as a seller. If forced, limiting the obligation to 'defend' rather than 'indemnify' significantly reduces Zebracorp's exposure.
content.conditions: Applies when suppliers request indemnities from Zebracorp for carve-out related claims.
content.justification: The text uses 'should not be taken for granted' and 'should not be expected to provide indemnities', indicating a strong stance. The advice to 'only agree to defend' is a critical mitigation strategy, making it High.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp avoids significant liability by resisting indemnities to the supplier, or by limiting its obligation to defense only.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier may not receive an indemnity from Zebracorp, or it will be limited to defense only.
content.source_insight: The text emphasizes the principle that indemnities flow from the selling party to the purchasing party.
content.text: The suppliers are fairly often likely to represent the viewpoint that Zebracorp should itself indemnify the supplier for any claims that are based on these carve-outs i.e. based on Zebracorp modifications etc. Such indemnities from Zebracorp to supplier should not be taken for granted. We should keep in mind that Zebracorp is not providing any products/services to the supplier against a fee and accordingly should not be expected to provide indemnities to the supplier. The indemnities should be provided by the selling party to the purchasing party. ... Instead of agreeing to indemnity the supplier for all costs and damages, we should seek to only agree to defend the supplier against the third party claim.

content.verbatim_text: Such clauses are not problematic, and can be accepted so long as we have agreed on the supplier’s liability for these IPR claims exclusively in the IP indemnity section of the agreement, which should practically always be the case.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can accept 'entire liability' and 'exclusive remedies' clauses if the supplier's IPR liability is exclusively defined within the IP indemnity section of the agreement.
content.expert_insight: These clauses consolidate liability, which is acceptable as long as the IP indemnity section itself is robust and comprehensive, ensuring Zebracorp's protection is not inadvertently limited by other contract sections.
content.conditions: If the supplier's IPR liability is exclusively defined in the IP indemnity section.
content.justification: The text states 'not problematic, and can be accepted' under a specific condition, indicating a medium importance, as long as the core protection is maintained.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp has clarity on the supplier's total liability for IPR claims, confined to the agreed indemnity terms.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's liability for IPR claims is limited to the specific indemnity provisions.
content.source_insight: The text confirms that this is a standard and generally acceptable clause.
content.text: Such clauses are not problematic, and can be accepted so long as we have agreed on the supplier’s liability for these IPR claims exclusively in the IP indemnity section of the agreement, which should practically always be the case.

content.verbatim_text: It is not uncommon for the seller to try to limit its liability for IPR infringement claims to any amounts that would have been due as a reasonable royalty based on the price of the seller’s products. ... Whilst the rationale behind such limitations is understandable, the effect of such limitation can put Zebracorp as substantial disadvantage, and these type of limitations should be carefully considered with IPR and/or Legal & Compliance.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must carefully consider and consult with IPR and/or Legal & Compliance regarding any supplier attempts to limit IPR liability to reasonable royalties based solely on the price of the seller's products.
content.expert_insight: This limitation can drastically undervalue the actual damages Zebracorp (or its customers) might incur, which are often tied to the value of Zebracorp's end product or solution. It's a significant risk that requires expert review.
content.conditions: Applies when suppliers attempt to limit liability to royalties based on their product price.
content.justification: The text highlights 'substantial disadvantage' and requires 'carefully considered with IPR and/or Legal & Compliance', indicating a high risk and the need for expert review.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp avoids potentially significant under-recovery of damages by carefully scrutinizing such limitations.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's liability may be broader than just royalties based on its product price.
content.source_insight: The text contrasts the value of an infringing component with the value of the Zebracorp system.
content.text: It is not uncommon for the seller to try to limit its liability for IPR infringement claims to any amounts that would have been due as a reasonable royalty based on the price of the seller’s products. ... Whilst the rationale behind such limitations is understandable, the effect of such limitation can put Zebracorp as substantial disadvantage, and these type of limitations should be carefully considered with IPR and/or Legal & Compliance.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp should be fully indemnified against any assertion that the deliverables provided by the supplier infringe any intellectual property rights of any third party. The indemnity should ideally be unlimited i.e. without monetary caps and without exclusion of indirect damages.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's preferred position is to be fully indemnified against any third-party IP infringement claims related to supplier deliverables. Ideally, this indemnity should be unlimited, without monetary caps or exclusion of indirect damages.
content.expert_insight: This sets the gold standard for Zebracorp's IPR protection, aiming for comprehensive coverage without financial limitations, which is crucial given the high costs and potential for indirect damages in IP litigation.
content.conditions: This is Zebracorp's ideal negotiating position.
content.justification: This is explicitly stated as 'Zebracorp Preferred Position' and describes the ideal, comprehensive protection, making it CRITICAL.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp aims for maximum protection, covering all types of damages without financial limits.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier faces potentially unlimited liability for IP infringement claims.
content.source_insight: This section summarizes Zebracorp's overarching objective for IPR indemnity.
content.text: Zebracorp should be fully indemnified against any assertion that the deliverables provided by the supplier infringe any intellectual property rights of any third party. The indemnity should ideally be unlimited i.e. without monetary caps and without exclusion of indirect damages.

content.verbatim_text: Whilst in many cases it would be in Zebracorp interest to have control over defense of such third party claims, we can agree that the supplier will take over the defense whenever this is reasonably feasible in practice. However, Supplier should not be allowed to enter into any settlement agreement that adversely affects Zebracorp without Zebracorp’s prior written consent. Also Zebracorp should have the right, at its own expense, to actively participate in any suit or proceeding, through its own counsel.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can agree to the supplier taking over defense if reasonably feasible, but must not allow the supplier to settle claims adversely affecting Zebracorp without prior written consent. Zebracorp should also retain the right to actively participate in defense, at its own expense, through its own counsel.
content.expert_insight: This balances the supplier's duty to defend with Zebracorp's need to protect its broader business interests, especially regarding settlements and active participation in critical cases.
content.conditions: Applies when negotiating the supplier's right to defend and settle claims.
content.justification: The text uses 'can agree' for supplier defense but 'should not be allowed' for adverse settlements, indicating a critical protection point. The right to participate is also a strong preference, making it High.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains control over critical decisions (settlements) and can participate in defense, protecting its reputation and business.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's control over defense and settlement is conditional on Zebracorp's consent for adverse settlements.
content.source_insight: This section outlines Zebracorp's preferred position on defense control.
content.text: Whilst in many cases it would be in Zebracorp interest to have control over defense of such third party claims, we can agree that the supplier will take over the defense whenever this is reasonably feasible in practice. However, Supplier should not be allowed to enter into any settlement agreement that adversely affects Zebracorp without Zebracorp’s prior written consent. Also Zebracorp should have the right, at its own expense, to actively participate in any suit or proceeding, through its own counsel.

content.verbatim_text: If it becomes apparent through contract negotiations that any material deviations from the standard IPR indemnity must be considered, it is recommended to engage a member of the Legal & Compliance team to determine if such deviations are appropriate and acceptable.
content.plain_text: If material deviations from the standard IPR indemnity are considered during negotiations, Zebracorp must engage a Legal & Compliance team member to assess their appropriateness and acceptability.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial procedural safeguard. Material deviations can introduce significant, unforeseen risks. Expert legal review is essential to protect Zebracorp's interests.
content.conditions: If material deviations from the standard IPR indemnity are considered during contract negotiations.
content.justification: The text uses 'must be considered' and 'recommended to engage', indicating a mandatory procedural step for high-risk situations, making it CRITICAL.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp ensures that any significant changes to IPR indemnity are thoroughly vetted by legal experts, mitigating risk.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier's proposed deviations will be subject to rigorous internal legal review by Zebracorp.

content.text: If it becomes apparent through contract negotiations that any material deviations from the standard IPR indemnity must be considered, it is recommended to engage a member of the Legal & Compliance team to determine if such deviations are appropriate and acceptable.

content.justification: Provides context on the expected difficulty and duration of IPR indemnity negotiations.

content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should anticipate that IPR indemnity clauses will be a significant and potentially difficult part of contract discussions.
