content.verbatim_text: The indemnity should apply to claims made in any country/jurisdiction in the world. However, it may be acceptable to agree that the indemnity will not apply in countries that do not provide adequate protection of intellectual property rights. This can be accomplished in e.g. by saying that the indemnity will not apply to claims made in countries that are not parties to the Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property. Any other geographic limitations should be carefully reviewed and discussed with Legal & Compliance.
content.plain_text: The indemnity should ideally cover worldwide claims. An exception may be made for countries lacking adequate IP protection (e.g., those not party to the Paris Convention). All other geographic limitations proposed by suppliers must be thoroughly reviewed and discussed with Legal & Compliance.
content.expert_insight: Global operations necessitate global IP protection. While pragmatic exceptions for weak IP regimes are understandable, any other geographic limits could expose Zebracorp to significant, unforeseen risks.
content.conditions: Negotiating the geographic scope of the indemnity.
content.justification: Ensures comprehensive protection for Zebracorp's global operations, while allowing for reasonable exceptions that do not significantly undermine protection.
content.implication_company: Broad geographic protection for Zebracorp, mitigating risks across its operational footprint.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's indemnity obligation extends globally, with limited, specific carve-outs for certain jurisdictions.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The indemnity should apply to claims made in any country/jurisdiction in the world. However, it may be acceptable to agree that the indemnity will not apply in countries that do not provide adequate protection of intellectual property rights. This can be accomplished in e.g. by saying that the indemnity will not apply to claims made in countries that are not parties to the Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property. Any other geographic limitations should be carefully reviewed and discussed with Legal & Compliance.

content.verbatim_text: Vendors are likely to request to delete the words “alleged infringement” from the scope of the indemnity and merely refer to “infringement of third party intellectual property rights”. The deletion of word “alleged” can be accepted if it is otherwise clear from the context that any infringement claim alone will trigger the indemnity.
content.plain_text: Vendors may request to remove 'alleged infringement' from the indemnity scope. This can be accepted if the contract context clearly indicates that an infringement claim itself triggers the indemnity, even if not yet proven.
content.expert_insight: This nuance is important for ensuring the indemnity covers the initial claim and defense costs, not just proven infringement, which is crucial for early-stage protection.
content.justification: Provides guidance on negotiating the term 'alleged infringement'.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp is protected from the outset of an infringement claim, not just after a final determination.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's obligation is triggered by a claim, not necessarily a proven infringement.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Vendors are likely to request to delete the words “alleged infringement” from the scope of the indemnity and merely refer to “infringement of third party intellectual property rights”. The deletion of word “alleged” can be accepted if it is otherwise clear from the context that any infringement claim alone will trigger the indemnity.

content.verbatim_text: The term “indemnify” and the term “hold harmless” are fairly similar to each other. Accordingly, we should be able to agree to delete the words “and hold harmless” from the indemnity provision as long as we retain the words “shall indemnify”. However, it is not recommended to delete the word “indemnify” and leave the term “hold harmless”. This is because in some countries, the term “hold harmless” does not have a well established legal meaning.
content.plain_text: While 'indemnify' and 'hold harmless' are similar, Zebracorp can agree to remove 'and hold harmless' if 'shall indemnify' is retained. It is not recommended to remove 'indemnify' and only keep 'hold harmless' due to the latter's unclear legal meaning in some jurisdictions.
content.expert_insight: Prioritizing 'indemnify' ensures the clause is legally robust and enforceable across jurisdictions, avoiding ambiguity that 'hold harmless' might introduce.
content.conditions: Negotiating the specific wording of the indemnity clause regarding 'indemnify' and 'hold harmless'.
content.justification: Ensures the indemnity clause uses legally well-established terminology to avoid ambiguity and potential unenforceability in certain jurisdictions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's indemnity protection is clearer and more legally sound.
content.implication_supplier: Clarifies the supplier's obligation under a recognized legal term.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The term “indemnify” and the term “hold harmless” are fairly similar to each other. Accordingly, we should be able to agree to delete the words “and hold harmless” from the indemnity provision as long as we retain the words “shall indemnify”. However, it is not recommended to delete the word “indemnify” and leave the term “hold harmless”. This is because in some countries, the term “hold harmless” does not have a well established legal meaning.

content.verbatim_text: However, we should be cautious to accept wording where we agree that the products must directly infringe third party intellectual property rights. This addition would imply that the product must itself infringe at the moment of delivery and would remove the supplier’s liability for any claims that are caused by the combination of the supplier product to our product. Excluding these type of combination claims should be addressed more specifically in the exclusion section of the indemnity (see below).
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should be cautious about accepting language that limits infringement to 'directly infringe,' as this could remove supplier liability for combination claims (where the supplier's product infringes when combined with Zebracorp's). Such exclusions should be explicitly addressed in the exclusions section.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical point, as 'direct infringement' can be interpreted narrowly, leaving Zebracorp exposed to significant 'combination claim' risks, which are common in complex IT systems.
content.conditions: Supplier proposes wording like 'directly infringe' in the indemnity scope.
content.justification: Prevents the supplier from escaping liability for 'combination claims' where their product, when integrated with Zebracorp's, causes infringement.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from bearing the risk of infringement arising from the integration of supplier products into its own systems.
content.implication_supplier: Maintains supplier's liability for infringement that occurs when their product is used in combination with others, as intended.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: However, we should be cautious to accept wording where we agree that the products must directly infringe third party intellectual property rights. This addition would imply that the product must itself infringe at the moment of delivery and would remove the supplier’s liability for any claims that are caused by the combination of the supplier product to our product. Excluding these type of combination claims should be addressed more specifically in the exclusion section of the indemnity (see below).

content.verbatim_text: Sophisticated vendors may attempt to limit their liability to reasonable royalties that are based upon revenue derived by the vendor from Zebracorp from sales or license of the infringing product. By making such limitation the vendor would attempt to confine its liability to the royalty payable for the number of infringing products sold by it to Zebracorp. This is generally not acceptable as this type of a limitation would rule out the vendor’s liability for any royalties that our end customer ends up paying to the third party claimant. It would also exclude the vendor’s liability for any royalties that are calculated on a per use basis or calculated in e.g. by the revenues made by the end user. In the event this request to exclude per-use royalties from the scope of the indemnity cannot be negotiated away, it is often preferable to agree to a monetary liability cap instead of agreeing to such request.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should generally reject vendor attempts to limit liability to royalties based solely on the vendor's revenue from Zebracorp. This limitation would exclude royalties paid by Zebracorp's end customers and per-use or end-user revenue-based royalties. If excluding per-use royalties cannot be negotiated away, a monetary liability cap is often a preferable alternative.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical financial protection. Limiting royalties to the vendor's direct revenue from Zebracorp creates a massive gap in coverage, leaving Zebracorp exposed to potentially much larger royalties based on end-customer use or revenue.
content.conditions: Supplier attempts to limit IPR liability to royalties based on its revenue from Zebracorp.
content.justification: Prevents Zebracorp from being liable for significant royalties that its end customers might pay, or for royalties calculated on usage or end-user revenue, which can be substantial.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from bearing substantial unrecoverable royalty costs that could arise from end-customer use or alternative royalty calculation methods.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's liability remains tied to the full scope of damages, including those related to end-customer use, unless a specific, negotiated monetary cap is in place.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Sophisticated vendors may attempt to limit their liability to reasonable royalties that are based upon revenue derived by the vendor from Zebracorp from sales or license of the infringing product. By making such limitation the vendor would attempt to confine its liability to the royalty payable for the number of infringing products sold by it to Zebracorp. This is generally not acceptable as this type of a limitation would rule out the vendor’s liability for any royalties that our end customer ends up paying to the third party claimant. It would also exclude the vendor’s liability for any royalties that are calculated on a per use basis or calculated in e.g. by the revenues made by the end user. In the event this request to exclude per-use royalties from the scope of the indemnity cannot be negotiated away, it is often preferable to agree to a monetary liability cap instead of agreeing to such request.

content.verbatim_text: The duty to defend is the obligation to provide a defense to a covered infringement claim.
content.plain_text: The duty to defend is the obligation to provide legal defense against an infringement claim that is covered by the indemnity.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies that the 'duty to defend' is a specific, active obligation to manage and fund the legal defense of a claim, distinct from simply paying damages.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The duty to defend is the obligation to provide a defense to a covered infringement claim.

content.verbatim_text: It is worth noting that the duty to defend and duty to indemnify are separate and distinct obligations, and because the duty to defend and the duty to indemnify are distinct obligations, the contract may impose a duty to defend the underlying claim even in the absence of a duty to indemnify.
content.plain_text: The duties to defend and to indemnify are separate obligations; a contract can impose a duty to defend an infringement claim even without a corresponding duty to indemnify.
content.expert_insight: This distinction is important for negotiation, as a supplier might be obligated to defend a claim even if the ultimate liability for damages falls elsewhere or is still being determined.
content.justification: Explains the distinction between the duty to defend and the duty to indemnify.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp may benefit from a defense even if the indemnity obligation is not yet clear or fully triggered.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier may have a defense obligation regardless of the final indemnity outcome.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: It is worth noting that the duty to defend and duty to indemnify are separate and distinct obligations, and because the duty to defend and the duty to indemnify are distinct obligations, the contract may impose a duty to defend the underlying claim even in the absence of a duty to indemnify.

content.verbatim_text: We should be careful in granting the supplier’s a right to defend the claim. As the (industry) customers of Zebracorp are typically the targets of the IPR infringement claim (and not us directly), and in quite many cases it is not a single component that is the solely infringing but rather certain system or a whole product used by the customer purchased from several vendors, it is unlikely that Zebracorp will in practice obtain full right to defend the case. This means that we should not offer the supplier unconditional and sole right and authority to defend the claims. Further, in those rare occasions where the supplier’s liability for IPR is capped or limtied, we obviously cannot allow the supplier to freely defend the case.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must be cautious in granting suppliers the sole right to defend IPR claims. Given that Zebracorp's customers are often the targets and claims frequently involve complex systems with multiple vendors, Zebracorp should not grant unconditional and sole defense authority. This is especially true if the supplier's IPR liability is capped or limited.
content.expert_insight: Granting sole defense rights to a supplier can create conflicts of interest, particularly when Zebracorp's reputation or broader product ecosystem is at stake, or when the supplier's financial exposure is capped. Zebracorp needs to retain control or significant oversight.
content.conditions: Supplier requests the right to defend the claim, especially if their IPR liability is capped or limited.
content.justification: Protects Zebracorp's interests, its customer relationships, and its broader product ecosystem from potentially misaligned defense strategies by a supplier, particularly when complex claims or capped liability are involved.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains critical control or influence over the defense of claims that impact its customers and business, preventing adverse outcomes.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's control over the defense is limited, especially when its liability is capped, requiring collaboration or allowing Zebracorp to maintain oversight.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: We should be careful in granting the supplier’s a right to defend the claim. As the (industry) customers of Zebracorp are typically the targets of the IPR infringement claim (and not us directly), and in quite many cases it is not a single component that is the solely infringing but rather certain system or a whole product used by the customer purchased from several vendors, it is unlikely that Zebracorp will in practice obtain full right to defend the case. This means that we should not offer the supplier unconditional and sole right and authority to defend the claims. Further, in those rare occasions where the supplier’s liability for IPR is capped or limtied, we obviously cannot allow the supplier to freely defend the case.

content.verbatim_text: Most IPR indemnities also include a specific provision defining the options (or depending on the wording) the obligations that the supplier has in the event of a third party IPR infringement claim.
content.plain_text: Most IPR indemnities include provisions outlining the supplier's options or obligations upon a third-party IPR infringement claim.
content.expert_insight: This sets the stage for understanding the proactive steps a supplier might take to mitigate or resolve an infringement, beyond just paying damages.
content.justification: Introduces the concept of ancillary obligations/options.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should expect these provisions in IPR indemnities.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier should be aware of these potential obligations.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Most IPR indemnities also include a specific provision defining the options (or depending on the wording) the obligations that the supplier has in the event of a third party IPR infringement claim.

content.verbatim_text: The above two options i.e. Design-Around and Substitution are largely non-contentious.
content.plain_text: The options for 'Design-Around' (modifying the product to avoid infringement) and 'Substitution' (obtaining a license) are generally not points of contention.
content.expert_insight: These are common and mutually beneficial solutions, as they allow for continued use of the product while resolving the infringement.
content.justification: Identifies common, non-contentious options.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can generally accept these options as beneficial solutions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers typically find these options acceptable for resolving infringement.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The above two options i.e. Design-Around and Substitution are largely non-contentious.

content.verbatim_text: However, the suppliers are likely to wish to introduce a third option, which effectively gives the supplier the right to require the return of the infringing products by agreeing to refund us the purchase price paid for the product, less a reasonable charge for depreciation and/or prior use. We should be careful when agreeing to accept this type of refund. In direct procurement contracts ZEBRACORP is likely to have sold and distributed the infringing products further to our end customers, and returning the products or requiring the end customer to cease further use of the product may cause irreparable damage and costs that far exceeds the potential royalties payable for the alleged infringement, or in worst case it may be impossible to comply with such request. Instead of agreeing to return the products or cease further use of the products, we should in such cases offer to agree to cease all further distribution and resale of the infringing products. When agreeing to this third option, we should also add language saying that this refund/right to cease further distribution of products is only available to the supplier in the event the two first options (i.e. the Design-Around and Substitution) are not reasonably feasible or achievable, and provided that we are given reasonable time to cease such further distribution. It is also recommended to include the following: “[Supplier] shall at all times act in such a way as to minimise interruption and disruption to the business operations of [ZEBRACORP] and its customers and contractors.” or substantially similar language to protect Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must be cautious about accepting a supplier's third option to require product return for a refund, as this can cause severe business disruption and costs, especially if products have been resold to end customers. Instead, propose ceasing further distribution and resale. If this third option is accepted, it must be conditional on the 'Design-Around' and 'Substitution' options not being feasible, and Zebracorp must be given reasonable time to cease distribution. Include language obligating the supplier to minimize business interruption for Zebracorp and its customers.
content.expert_insight: This guideline protects Zebracorp from highly disruptive and costly product recalls or forced cessation of use, which can severely damage customer relationships and business continuity. Prioritizing less disruptive solutions and ensuring adequate time and supplier responsibility for minimizing impact are crucial.
content.conditions: Supplier proposes a 'return and refund' option for infringing products.
content.justification: Minimizes severe business disruption, irreparable damage to customer relationships, and costs for Zebracorp that would result from forced product returns or cessation of use after distribution.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp's business continuity and customer relationships by ensuring less disruptive resolution options are prioritized and providing time for adjustment.
content.implication_supplier: Limits the supplier's ability to force product returns, requiring them to prioritize design-around or licensing solutions and consider Zebracorp's business impact.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: However, the suppliers are likely to wish to introduce a third option, which effectively gives the supplier the right to require the return of the infringing products by agreeing to refund us the purchase price paid for the product, less a reasonable charge for depreciation and/or prior use. We should be careful when agreeing to accept this type of refund. In direct procurement contracts ZEBRACORP is likely to have sold and distributed the infringing products further to our end customers, and returning the products or requiring the end customer to cease further use of the product may cause irreparable damage and costs that far exceeds the potential royalties payable for the alleged infringement, or in worst case it may be impossible to comply with such request. Instead of agreeing to return the products or cease further use of the products, we should in such cases offer to agree to cease all further distribution and resale of the infringing products. When agreeing to this third option, we should also add language saying that this refund/right to cease further distribution of products is only available to the supplier in the event the two first options (i.e. the Design-Around and Substitution) are not reasonably feasible or achievable, and provided that we are given reasonable time to cease such further distribution. It is also recommended to include the following: “[Supplier] shall at all times act in such a way as to minimise interruption and disruption to the business operations of [ZEBRACORP] and its customers and contractors.” or substantially similar language to protect Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: It is important to mention that the supplier is not relieved from its obligation to indemnify Zebracorp by simply picking one of the above three options. This is because Zebracorp is likely to have already incurred damages and costs even if the supplier proves successful in implementing in e.g. a design-around that removes the infringement. This is achieved by including the word: “…without prejudice to its indemnity obligation…” in the above example provision.
content.plain_text: The supplier's indemnity obligation to Zebracorp is not relieved by choosing one of the remedial options (Design-Around, Substitution, or Refund/Return), as Zebracorp may have already incurred damages and costs. This should be explicitly stated, for example, with the phrase 'without prejudice to its indemnity obligation.'
content.expert_insight: This ensures Zebracorp is made whole for all damages, even those incurred before a remedial option is implemented, preventing the supplier from using a 'fix' to escape prior liabilities.
content.conditions: Drafting or reviewing clauses related to supplier's ancillary obligations/options.
content.justification: Ensures Zebracorp is fully compensated for all damages and costs incurred due to infringement, regardless of the supplier's chosen remedial action.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can recover all damages, including those incurred before a solution is implemented.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier remains liable for all damages, even if they successfully implement a remedial option.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: It is important to mention that the supplier is not relieved from its obligation to indemnify Zebracorp by simply picking one of the above three options. This is because Zebracorp is likely to have already incurred damages and costs even if the supplier proves successful in implementing in e.g. a design-around that removes the infringement. This is achieved by including the word: “…without prejudice to its indemnity obligation…” in the above example provision.

content.verbatim_text: In some of our procurement contract templates, the above options have been defined as obligations of the supplier rather than alternatives that are available to the supplier. There should be no harm in rephrasing the clause so that these obligations are transferred to options, so long as it is clear from the context that choosing one or another of these options does not negate the obligation of the supplier to indemnify Zebracorp for any damages we may have incurred as a result of the IPR claim.
content.plain_text: If contract templates define remedial options as supplier obligations, rephrasing them as options is acceptable, provided it's clear that exercising an option does not negate the supplier's indemnity obligation for incurred damages.
content.expert_insight: This provides drafting flexibility while reiterating the critical principle that the indemnity obligation is separate and distinct from the remedial actions.
content.justification: Provides guidance on rephrasing ancillary obligations.
content.implication_company: Maintains Zebracorp's right to indemnity regardless of supplier's chosen remedy.
content.implication_supplier: Clarifies that remedial actions do not replace the indemnity obligation.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In some of our procurement contract templates, the above options have been defined as obligations of the supplier rather than alternatives that are available to the supplier. There should be no harm in rephrasing the clause so that these obligations are transferred to options, so long as it is clear from the context that choosing one or another of these options does not negate the obligation of the supplier to indemnify Zebracorp for any damages we may have incurred as a result of the IPR claim.

content.verbatim_text: The purpose of these requirements is to ensure that the party benefiting from the indemnity does not exacerbate the losses suffered by the party giving the indemnity.
content.plain_text: The purpose of indemnitee obligations is to prevent the indemnified party from worsening the losses for the indemnitor.
content.expert_insight: This explains the rationale behind indemnitee obligations, ensuring that Zebracorp acts responsibly to mitigate damages, which is a common legal principle.
content.justification: Explains the purpose of indemnitee obligations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp has a responsibility to mitigate damages to avoid exacerbating supplier's losses.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier seeks to ensure Zebracorp acts to minimize losses.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The purpose of these requirements is to ensure that the party benefiting from the indemnity does not exacerbate the losses suffered by the party giving the indemnity.

content.verbatim_text: These obligations customarily include .i the obligation to notify the indemnitor of the third party claim and ii. the obligation to surrender the defence of the claim over to the indemnitor.
content.plain_text: Customary obligations for the indemnitee include notifying the indemnitor of third-party claims and surrendering the defense of the claim to the indemnitor.
content.expert_insight: These are standard procedural requirements that ensure the indemnitor is aware of the claim and can take appropriate action to defend it.
content.justification: Lists customary indemnitee obligations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must adhere to these procedural requirements to benefit from the indemnity.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier expects timely notification and control over the defense.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: These obligations customarily include .i the obligation to notify the indemnitor of the third party claim and ii. the obligation to surrender the defence of the claim over to the indemnitor.

content.verbatim_text: Care should be taken when agreeing to notify the supplier of the infringement claim. Ideally we should undertake to inform the supplier of the claim “within a reasonable time period”. If this is rejected by the supplier, we could agree to inform “without any undue delay”. However, we should not agree to wording such as “immediately” or “promptly” as any inadvertent delay may give the supplier a case for trying to walk away from the entire indemnity obligation. In the event the supplier is adamant about using the words “promptly” or “immediately”, we should consider adding in e.g. the following clarifying language: “failure by the [buyer] to inform the [supplier] of any claim in a timely manner will only affect the obligations of the [supplier] if and to the extent the [supplier] is directly prejudiced as a result of such delay”.
content.plain_text: When agreeing to notify the supplier of an infringement claim, Zebracorp should aim for 'within a reasonable time period,' or 'without any undue delay' as a fallback. Avoid 'immediately' or 'promptly,' as minor delays could allow the supplier to escape indemnity. If the supplier insists on 'promptly' or 'immediately,' add clarifying language stating that Zebracorp's failure to notify only affects supplier obligations if the supplier is directly prejudiced by the delay.
content.expert_insight: This guideline is crucial for preventing technical breaches from voiding the indemnity. It balances the supplier's need for timely notice with Zebracorp's operational realities, ensuring that only actual harm from delay impacts the supplier's obligations.
content.conditions: Negotiating the timing for notifying the supplier of an infringement claim.
content.justification: Protects Zebracorp from losing indemnity rights due to minor, non-prejudicial delays in notification, which can occur inadvertently.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains its indemnity rights even if notification is not instantaneous, provided no direct prejudice to the supplier.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier receives timely notification, but cannot use minor delays as an excuse to avoid indemnity unless actual prejudice is proven.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Care should be taken when agreeing to notify the supplier of the infringement claim. Ideally we should undertake to inform the supplier of the claim “within a reasonable time period”. If this is rejected by the supplier, we could agree to inform “without any undue delay”. However, we should not agree to wording such as “immediately” or “promptly” as any inadvertent delay may give the supplier a case for trying to walk away from the entire indemnity obligation. In the event the supplier is adamant about using the words “promptly” or “immediately”, we should consider adding in e.g. the following clarifying language: “failure by the [buyer] to inform the [supplier] of any claim in a timely manner will only affect the obligations of the [supplier] if and to the extent the [supplier] is directly prejudiced as a result of such delay”.

content.verbatim_text: It is customary for the supplier to be given the right to conduct the defense of the claim to the extent this is practically feasible. The reason for this is that the supplier may think that the claim is frivolous or otherwise without merit or that the claim can be easily defended, whereas the purchasing party may simply wish to get itself out of the dispute by settling with the claimant.
content.plain_text: It is customary for the supplier to have the right to conduct the defense of a claim, if feasible. This is because the supplier may believe the claim is without merit or easily defensible, while the purchasing party might prefer a quick settlement.
content.expert_insight: This explains the common dynamic where the indemnitor (supplier) wants control over the defense to manage costs and strategy, while the indemnitee (Zebracorp) might prioritize quick resolution.
content.justification: Explains the customary right of supplier to conduct defense.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should understand the supplier's motivation for wanting to control the defense.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier typically seeks control to manage defense strategy and costs.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: It is customary for the supplier to be given the right to conduct the defense of the claim to the extent this is practically feasible. The reason for this is that the supplier may think that the claim is frivolous or otherwise without merit or that the claim can be easily defended, whereas the purchasing party may simply wish to get itself out of the dispute by settling with the claimant.

content.verbatim_text: Note however that we should not allow the supplier to take control over the defense/settlement of the claim in the event we agree to cap the supplier’s liability for the claims. Please consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team on how to revise the indemnity and defense provisions in such case.
content.plain_text: If the supplier's liability for IPR claims is capped, Zebracorp must not allow the supplier to control the defense or settlement. Consult Legal & Compliance for appropriate revisions to indemnity and defense provisions in such scenarios.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical safeguard. A capped liability creates a conflict of interest for the supplier, who might prioritize minimizing their capped exposure over Zebracorp's broader interests. Zebracorp must retain control to protect itself from adverse outcomes.
content.conditions: Supplier's IPR liability is capped.
content.justification: Prevents a conflict of interest where a supplier with capped liability might make defense or settlement decisions that are detrimental to Zebracorp's uncapped exposure.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains control over defense and settlement to protect its interests when supplier's liability is capped.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier loses control over defense and settlement when its liability is capped, requiring Zebracorp's involvement.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Note however that we should not allow the supplier to take control over the defense/settlement of the claim in the event we agree to cap the supplier’s liability for the claims. Please consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team on how to revise the indemnity and defense provisions in such case.

content.verbatim_text: ZEBRACORP’s duty to cooperate in defending the claim should be subject to such cooperation being reasonable. We would also expect to be compensated for the costs that we incur from providing such assistance. If this point becomes contentious, we can agree to cooperate and assist at our own cost so long as our cooperation obligation is limited to whatever is ‘reasonably’ required by the supplier.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's duty to cooperate in defending a claim should be limited to what is 'reasonable,' and Zebracorp expects compensation for its cooperation costs. If compensation is contentious, Zebracorp can agree to cooperate at its own cost, provided the cooperation obligation remains 'reasonably' required by the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This balances Zebracorp's responsibility to assist with the supplier's defense against the need to avoid undue burden and uncompensated costs. The 'reasonable' qualifier is key to managing Zebracorp's obligations.
content.conditions: Negotiating Zebracorp's cooperation duties and compensation for assistance in defense.
content.justification: Ensures Zebracorp is not unduly burdened by assisting in the supplier's defense and is compensated for its efforts, or at least limits its uncompensated efforts to reasonable requirements.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's cooperation is limited and potentially compensated, protecting its resources.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier receives reasonable cooperation from Zebracorp, and may bear the costs of that cooperation.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: ZEBRACORP’s duty to cooperate in defending the claim should be subject to such cooperation being reasonable. We would also expect to be compensated for the costs that we incur from providing such assistance. If this point becomes contentious, we can agree to cooperate and assist at our own cost so long as our cooperation obligation is limited to whatever is ‘reasonably’ required by the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: The Supplier may also require that Zebracorp (as the party benefiting from indemnity) will refrain from admitting liability in third party claims and will refrain from settling such claim without the supplier’s express prior written consent. This is generally acceptable.
content.plain_text: It is generally acceptable for the supplier to require Zebracorp to refrain from admitting liability or settling third-party claims without the supplier's prior written consent.
content.expert_insight: This is a standard clause that allows the indemnitor to control the defense strategy and avoid actions by the indemnitee that could prejudice the defense or increase costs.
content.justification: Provides guidance on accepting supplier's requirements regarding admission of liability and settlement.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must coordinate with the supplier on liability admissions and settlements.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier maintains control over key defense decisions.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The Supplier may also require that Zebracorp (as the party benefiting from indemnity) will refrain from admitting liability in third party claims and will refrain from settling such claim without the supplier’s express prior written consent. This is generally acceptable.

content.verbatim_text: The suppliers will in most cases insist on excluding their liability for infringement claims that are caused by certain excluded conduct. A typical carve-out clause has three elements: i. unauthorized modifications ii. combination claims and iii. compliance with buyer specifications.
content.plain_text: Suppliers typically seek to exclude liability for infringement claims resulting from specific conduct, usually unauthorized modifications, combination claims, or compliance with buyer specifications.
content.expert_insight: This identifies common areas where suppliers try to limit their liability, shifting risk back to Zebracorp for actions or specifications outside the supplier's control.
content.justification: Explains typical carve-outs in indemnity clauses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should anticipate these carve-outs and be prepared to negotiate them.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers commonly propose these exclusions to limit their risk.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The suppliers will in most cases insist on excluding their liability for infringement claims that are caused by certain excluded conduct. A typical carve-out clause has three elements: i. unauthorized modifications ii. combination claims and iii. compliance with buyer specifications.

content.verbatim_text: Care should be taken in negotiating these carve-outs. In each case it is worth mentioning specifically that the supplier will not benefit from the exclusion if the infringement would not have occurred without the modification or combination made by buyer or without buyer specification. As regards to unauthorized modifications or combinations, we should try to include language that shifts the liability back to the supplier in cases where the supplier has separately given its consent to the modification or combination even if the modification or combination was not authorized in the products specifications. This can be done by adding the words ‘without supplier’s consent’ in the above example. When agreeing to exclude the supplier’s liability for combination claims, it is generally acceptable to specify that: “the [Supplier] will have no liability for these combination claims for the portion of the obligation or liability determined on a fair and equitable basis to be attributable to a party other than the [Supplier] based on the materiality of the [Supplier products] to the combination claim”. As for the carve-out on Zebracorp provided specifications, it is important to stress that the specifications have to be mandated by Zebracorp without any freedom of design for the supplier in order for the supplier to be able to shift the liability for IP infringement to Zebracorp. In most cases, Zebracorp will have to rely on the expertise of the supplier in building and designing the product, and the mere fact that Zebracorp provides certain requirements/specifications for the products it purchases should not transfer the risk of IP infringements over to Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Negotiate carve-outs carefully, ensuring the supplier remains liable if infringement would have occurred regardless of Zebracorp's actions (modification, combination, or specification). For modifications/combinations, include language shifting liability back to the supplier if they consented. For combination claims, an exclusion for the portion attributable to another party based on the supplier product's materiality is generally acceptable. For Zebracorp-provided specifications, liability should only shift if Zebracorp mandated them without any design freedom for the supplier, as Zebracorp typically relies on supplier expertise.
content.expert_insight: This comprehensive guideline ensures that carve-outs are narrowly defined and do not inadvertently shift core IP infringement risks from the supplier to Zebracorp, especially when Zebracorp relies on the supplier's design expertise.
content.conditions: Negotiating typical carve-outs (unauthorized modifications, combination claims, buyer specifications).
content.justification: Prevents suppliers from broadly escaping liability for infringement by ensuring carve-outs are narrowly applied to situations where Zebracorp's actions truly caused the infringement, and not for inherent product flaws or where supplier had design freedom.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp avoids bearing undue liability for IP infringement, particularly in complex product integrations or when relying on supplier expertise.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's liability for infringement remains, except for clearly defined instances where Zebracorp's actions are the direct cause, and where the supplier lacked design freedom.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Care should be taken in negotiating these carve-outs. In each case it is worth mentioning specifically that the supplier will not benefit from the exclusion if the infringement would not have occurred without the modification or combination made by buyer or without buyer specification. As regards to unauthorized modifications or combinations, we should try to include language that shifts the liability back to the supplier in cases where the supplier has separately given its consent to the modification or combination even if the modification or combination was not authorized in the products specifications. This can be done by adding the words ‘without supplier’s consent’ in the above example. When agreeing to exclude the supplier’s liability for combination claims, it is generally acceptable to specify that: “the [Supplier] will have no liability for these combination claims for the portion of the obligation or liability determined on a fair and equitable basis to be attributable to a party other than the [Supplier] based on the materiality of the [Supplier products] to the combination claim”. As for the carve-out on Zebracorp provided specifications, it is important to stress that the specifications have to be mandated by Zebracorp without any freedom of design for the supplier in order for the supplier to be able to shift the liability for IP infringement to Zebracorp. In most cases, Zebracorp will have to rely on the expertise of the supplier in building and designing the product, and the mere fact that Zebracorp provides certain requirements/specifications for the products it purchases should not transfer the risk of IP infringements over to Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: Another common carve-out proposed by sophisticated vendors seeks to exclude ‘all claims asserted by a company, which exercises control over Zebracorp or which is controlled by Zebracorp’. This carve out essentially prevents Zebracorp from taking advantage of the indemnity when the third party making the infringement claim is in fact not a third party but an affiliated company of Zebracorp. Such carve-outs are generally acceptable.
content.plain_text: A common carve-out excludes claims from Zebracorp's affiliated companies (those controlling or controlled by Zebracorp). This is generally acceptable as it prevents Zebracorp from using the indemnity for internal group claims.
content.expert_insight: This is a reasonable exclusion, as indemnities are designed for third-party risks, not internal corporate disputes.
content.justification: Provides guidance on accepting affiliate claims carve-outs.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp cannot use the indemnity for claims originating from its own affiliates.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier is protected from claims originating from Zebracorp's corporate group.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Another common carve-out proposed by sophisticated vendors seeks to exclude ‘all claims asserted by a company, which exercises control over Zebracorp or which is controlled by Zebracorp’. This carve out essentially prevents Zebracorp from taking advantage of the indemnity when the third party making the infringement claim is in fact not a third party but an affiliated company of Zebracorp. Such carve-outs are generally acceptable.

content.verbatim_text: The suppliers are fairly often likely to represent the viewpoint that Zebracorp should itself indemnify the supplier for any claims that are based on these carve-outs i.e. based on Zebracorp modifications etc. Such indemnities from Zebracorp to supplier should not be taken for granted. We should keep in mind that Zebracorp is not providing any products/services to the supplier against a fee and accordingly should not be expected to provide indemnities to the supplier. The indemnities should be provided by the selling party to the purchasing party. Whenever the supplier is requesting an indemnity from Zebracorp it is worth asking the supplier whether the supplier would in fact be willing to indemnify Zebracorp in the event the supplier would provide products to Zebracorp free of charge. That being said, agreeing to this type of indemnity is not out of the question. If worded carefully the indemnity can be used to limit Zebracorp’s liability in cases where Zebracorp does cause a third party infringement claim by its own actions. Instead of agreeing to indemnity the supplier for all costs and damages, we should seek to only agree to defend the supplier against the third party claim.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should not automatically agree to indemnify the supplier for claims arising from carve-outs (e.g., Zebracorp's modifications), as Zebracorp is the purchasing party, not providing paid services. Indemnities typically flow from seller to buyer. If Zebracorp does agree to such an indemnity, it should be carefully worded to limit Zebracorp's liability to cases where its actions caused infringement, and ideally, Zebracorp should only agree to defend the supplier against the third-party claim, not fully indemnify them for all costs and damages.
content.expert_insight: This guideline protects Zebracorp from accepting a 'reverse indemnity' that is misaligned with the commercial relationship. If such an indemnity is unavoidable, limiting it to a 'duty to defend' significantly reduces Zebracorp's financial exposure.
content.conditions: Supplier requests Zebracorp to indemnify them for claims based on carve-outs.
content.justification: Prevents Zebracorp from taking on inappropriate indemnity obligations as the purchasing party, and if an indemnity is necessary, limits its scope to defense rather than full financial liability.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp avoids unnecessary or overly broad indemnity obligations to suppliers, protecting its financial position.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier may not receive full indemnity from Zebracorp for carve-out related claims, potentially only a duty to defend.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The suppliers are fairly often likely to represent the viewpoint that Zebracorp should itself indemnify the supplier for any claims that are based on these carve-outs i.e. based on Zebracorp modifications etc. Such indemnities from Zebracorp to supplier should not be taken for granted. We should keep in mind that Zebracorp is not providing any products/services to the supplier against a fee and accordingly should not be expected to provide indemnities to the supplier. The indemnities should be provided by the selling party to the purchasing party. Whenever the supplier is requesting an indemnity from Zebracorp it is worth asking the supplier whether the supplier would in fact be willing to indemnify Zebracorp in the event the supplier would provide products to Zebracorp free of charge. That being said, agreeing to this type of indemnity is not out of the question. If worded carefully the indemnity can be used to limit Zebracorp’s liability in cases where Zebracorp does cause a third party infringement claim by its own actions. Instead of agreeing to indemnity the supplier for all costs and damages, we should seek to only agree to defend the supplier against the third party claim.

content.verbatim_text: It is fairly customary for the supplier to wish to expressly state that the indemnities and ancillary obligations agreed in the IP indemnity section of the agreement constitute the purchasing party’s sole remedies and the supplier’s sole liability... Such clauses are not problematic, and can be accepted so long as we have agreed on the supplier’s liability for these IPR claims exclusively in the IP indemnity section of the agreement, which should practically always be the case.
content.plain_text: It is customary and acceptable for suppliers to state that the IP indemnity section constitutes Zebracorp's sole remedies and the supplier's sole liability, provided that all supplier IPR liability has been exclusively defined within that section.
content.expert_insight: This 'sole remedies' clause provides clarity and limits the supplier's exposure by consolidating all IPR-related remedies into one section, preventing claims under other contract provisions.
content.justification: Provides guidance on accepting 'sole remedies' clauses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's IPR remedies are confined to the indemnity section, ensuring clarity.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's IPR liability is clearly defined and limited to the indemnity section.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: It is fairly customary for the supplier to wish to expressly state that the indemnities and ancillary obligations agreed in the IP indemnity section of the agreement constitute the purchasing party’s sole remedies and the supplier’s sole liability... Such clauses are not problematic, and can be accepted so long as we have agreed on the supplier’s liability for these IPR claims exclusively in the IP indemnity section of the agreement, which should practically always be the case.

content.verbatim_text: It is not uncommon for the seller to try to limit its liability for IPR infringement claims to any amounts that would have been due as a reasonable royalty based on the price of the seller’s products. The sellers include this limitation so as to ensure that they end up paying royalties or license fees to a third party based on the value of their product as opposed to value of the Zebracorp product/solution. The difference between the two can be substantial as an example for a component supplier where the value of the infringing component is far lower than the value of in e.g. the Zebracorp system that incorporates the infringing component. Whilst the rationale behind such limitations is understandable, the effect of such limitation can put Zebracorp as substantial disadvantage, and these type of limitations should be carefully considered with IPR and/or Legal & Compliance.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must carefully consider and consult IPR/Legal & Compliance regarding seller attempts to limit IPR liability to royalties based solely on the seller's product price. This can severely disadvantage Zebracorp if the infringing component's value is much lower than the overall Zebracorp product/solution it's integrated into.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical financial risk. Such a limitation can leave Zebracorp responsible for the vast majority of damages when an inexpensive component infringes IP within a high-value Zebracorp system. It fundamentally misallocates risk.
content.conditions: Seller attempts to limit IPR liability to royalties based on the price of their products.
content.justification: Prevents Zebracorp from bearing a disproportionately large share of infringement damages when the value of the infringing component is small compared to the overall Zebracorp product/solution.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from substantial financial disadvantage and unrecoverable costs related to the overall value of its products/solutions.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's liability remains tied to the actual damages, which may be significantly higher than the value of their individual component.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: It is not uncommon for the seller to try to limit its liability for IPR infringement claims to any amounts that would have been due as a reasonable royalty based on the price of the seller’s products. The sellers include this limitation so as to ensure that they end up paying royalties or license fees to a third party based on the value of their product as opposed to value of the Zebracorp product/solution. The difference between the two can be substantial as an example for a component supplier where the value of the infringing component is far lower than the value of in e.g. the Zebracorp system that incorporates the infringing component. Whilst the rationale behind such limitations is understandable, the effect of such limitation can put Zebracorp as substantial disadvantage, and these type of limitations should be carefully considered with IPR and/or Legal & Compliance.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp should be fully indemnified against any assertion that the deliverables provided by the supplier infringe any intellectual property rights of any third party. The indemnity should ideally be unlimited i.e. without monetary caps and without exclusion of indirect damages.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's preferred position is to be fully indemnified against any third-party IPR infringement claims related to supplier deliverables. Ideally, this indemnity should be unlimited, meaning no monetary caps and no exclusion of indirect damages.
content.expert_insight: This defines Zebracorp's optimal negotiating stance: maximum protection with no financial limits, ensuring complete risk transfer for supplier-caused IP infringement.
content.conditions: Establishing Zebracorp's preferred negotiating position for IPR indemnity.
content.justification: Ensures Zebracorp receives the highest level of protection, covering all potential damages and costs without arbitrary limits, aligning with the core purpose of an indemnity.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp aims for comprehensive, unlimited protection from IPR infringement risks.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier faces the highest potential liability without caps or exclusion of indirect damages.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Zebracorp should be fully indemnified against any assertion that the deliverables provided by the supplier infringe any intellectual property rights of any third party. The indemnity should ideally be unlimited i.e. without monetary caps and without exclusion of indirect damages.

content.verbatim_text: However, it is important to remember that an indemnity is only as good as the creditworthiness of the party making the indemnity.
content.plain_text: An indemnity's effectiveness is directly dependent on the indemnifying party's financial creditworthiness.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial practical consideration: even a perfectly drafted indemnity is worthless if the indemnitor cannot fulfill their financial obligations. Due diligence on supplier solvency is important.
content.justification: Highlights a practical limitation of indemnities.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should consider the supplier's financial stability when relying on an indemnity.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: However, it is important to remember that an indemnity is only as good as the creditworthiness of the party making the indemnity.

content.verbatim_text: Whilst in many cases it would be in Zebracorp interest to have control over defense of such third party claims, we can agree that the supplier will take over the defense whenever this is reasonably feasible in practice. However, Supplier should not be allowed to enter into any settlement agreement that adversely affects Zebracorp without Zebracorp’s prior written consent. Also Zebracorp should have the right, at its own expense, to actively participate in any suit or proceeding, through its own counsel.
content.plain_text: While Zebracorp prefers to control the defense of third-party IPR claims, it can agree to the supplier taking over the defense if practically feasible. However, the supplier must not settle in a way that adversely affects Zebracorp without its prior written consent. Zebracorp also retains the right to actively participate in any proceedings, at its own expense, through its own counsel.
content.expert_insight: This balances the practical benefits of supplier-led defense with Zebracorp's need to protect its broader business interests, especially regarding settlements and the right to monitor the defense.
content.conditions: Negotiating control over the defense of third-party IPR claims.
content.justification: Ensures Zebracorp retains control over critical decisions (like settlement) that could impact its business, even if the supplier manages the day-to-day defense.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp protects its interests and reputation by retaining veto power over adverse settlements and the right to participate in the defense.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier can manage the defense but is constrained by Zebracorp's consent for settlements and its right to participate.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Whilst in many cases it would be in Zebracorp interest to have control over defense of such third party claims, we can agree that the supplier will take over the defense whenever this is reasonably feasible in practice. However, Supplier should not be allowed to enter into any settlement agreement that adversely affects Zebracorp without Zebracorp’s prior written consent. Also Zebracorp should have the right, at its own expense, to actively participate in any suit or proceeding, through its own counsel.

content.verbatim_text: If it becomes apparent through contract negotiations that any material deviations from the standard IPR indemnity must be considered, it is recommended to engage a member of the Legal & Compliance team to determine if such deviations are appropriate and acceptable.

content.expert_insight: This foundational definition highlights the core purpose of an indemnity: risk transfer and compensation for specified losses. It's crucial to understand the roles of Indemnitor and Indemnitee.

content.verbatim_text: The indemnity provision allows the parties to agree on a set of costs and damages that must be reimbursed in the event certain facts or circumstances occur.
content.plain_text: Indemnity provisions enable parties to define specific costs and damages that will be reimbursed if certain conditions are met.
content.expert_insight: Unlike general breach of contract claims, an indemnity allows for pre-agreed scope of recoverable damages, which can be broader than common law limitations.
content.justification: Explains the function of an indemnity provision.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use indemnity provisions to ensure specific costs related to third-party IP infringement are covered by the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: In a standard action for breach of contract, the amount of money that may be recovered by the claimant is limited by various legal filters, such as a requirement that the damages must be foreseeable, unavoidable and reasonable. In the event the contract specifies that certain damages will be recoverable on an indemnity basis, then the level of damages will depend upon the drafting of the indemnity, and the damages need not necessarily be limited by the above referred filters.
content.plain_text: Unlike standard breach of contract claims where damages are limited by foreseeability, unavoidability, and reasonableness, damages recoverable under an indemnity depend on its specific drafting and may not be subject to these legal filters.
content.expert_insight: This distinction is critical. Indemnities can provide a broader scope of recovery than common law breach claims, making their drafting paramount for both parties.
content.justification: Compares and contrasts indemnity with breach of contract claims regarding damage recovery.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can potentially recover a wider range of damages under a well-drafted indemnity than under a typical breach of contract claim.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers face potentially higher and less constrained liability under an indemnity compared to a standard breach of contract claim.
content.source_insight: The text provides information on the legal implications of indemnity vs. breach of contract.
content.text: In a standard action for breach of contract, the amount of money that may be recovered by the claimant is limited by various legal filters, such as a requirement that the damages must be foreseeable, unavoidable and reasonable. In the event the contract specifies that certain damages will be recoverable on an indemnity basis, then the level of damages will depend upon the drafting of the indemnity, and the damages need not necessarily be limited by the above referred filters.

content.verbatim_text: The purpose of the Intellectual Property Rights indemnity provision is to make Zebracorp whole against any damages and costs Zebracorp may suffer as a result of the supplier’s products/services infringing any third party intellectual property rights (IPR).
content.plain_text: The IPR indemnity provision aims to fully compensate Zebracorp for damages and costs incurred due to supplier products/services infringing third-party intellectual property rights.
content.expert_insight: This states the core objective from Zebracorp's perspective: full protection against IP infringement liabilities arising from supplier offerings.
content.justification: Defines the specific purpose of IPR indemnity for Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp expects to be fully protected from financial harm if supplier products infringe third-party IPR.
