content.verbatim_text: An IPR indemnity is a standard feature in any contract for the sale of hardware, or software license, or any a commissioned software or hardware development, or any IT consultancy services contract. This is chiefly due to the fact that intellectual property rights litigations are relatively commonplace in the IT/Telco industry.
content.plain_text: IPR indemnities are standard in hardware sales, software licenses, commissioned IT development, and IT consultancy contracts, primarily because IP litigation is common in the IT/Telco industry.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the industry-specific necessity of IPR indemnities, driven by the high frequency of IP disputes in IT/Telco sectors.
content.justification: Explains why IPR indemnities are standard in certain contract types and the underlying reason.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should always expect and include IPR indemnity in relevant IT/Telco contracts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers in the IT/Telco industry should anticipate IPR indemnity clauses as a standard contractual requirement.
content.source_insight: The text provides industry context and common practices.
content.text: An IPR indemnity is a standard feature in any contract for the sale of hardware, or software license, or any a commissioned software or hardware development, or any IT consultancy services contract. This is chiefly due to the fact that intellectual property rights litigations are relatively commonplace in the IT/Telco industry.

content.verbatim_text: In contrast to copyright infringement where infringement customarily requires intentional or knowing copying of someone else’s copyrighted material, patent infringement can occur without any culpable behaviour on the part of the infringer. Knowledge of the existing patent or an intention to infringe the patent is by and large irrelevant. In fact, it may admittedly be next to impossible for a vendor of sophisticated IT product to ensure that product does not infringe any third party patents anywhere in the world. It is therefore not unusual that IPR indemnity provisions are both time consuming and difficult to conclude.
content.plain_text: Unlike copyright infringement, which typically requires intentional copying, patent infringement can occur unknowingly, as intent or knowledge of the patent is largely irrelevant. It's often impossible for IT vendors to guarantee their products don't infringe global patents, making IPR indemnity negotiations complex and lengthy.
content.expert_insight: This explains the unique challenges of patent infringement, justifying the critical nature and negotiation difficulty of IPR indemnities, especially for suppliers.
content.justification: Provides context on the nature of patent infringement and its impact on IPR indemnity negotiations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be aware of the inherent difficulty for suppliers regarding patent infringement, which may influence negotiation tactics but not the core requirement for indemnity.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers face a high burden in avoiding patent infringement, making robust IPR indemnity clauses a significant risk area for them.
content.source_insight: The text provides detailed information on the nature of IP infringement and its implications.
content.text: In contrast to copyright infringement where infringement customarily requires intentional or knowing copying of someone else’s copyrighted material, patent infringement can occur without any culpable behaviour on the part of the infringer. Knowledge of the existing patent or an intention to infringe the patent is by and large irrelevant. In fact, it may admittedly be next to impossible for a vendor of sophisticated IT product to ensure that product does not infringe any third party patents anywhere in the world. It is therefore not unusual that IPR indemnity provisions are both time consuming and difficult to conclude.

content.verbatim_text: “The [Supplier] shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless [Zebracorp] and its Affiliates at its own expense from and against any claims, actions, liabilities, damages, costs and expenses (including but not limited to attorney's fees and costs) incurred by the [Zebracorp], its Affiliates or their respective customers and contractors as a result of infringement or alleged infringement of any intellectual property rights of any third parties by any [products and deliverable sold or licensed hereunder.”
content.plain_text: An example IPR indemnity clause states that the Supplier must indemnify, defend, and hold harmless Zebracorp and its Affiliates, at the Supplier's expense, against all claims, actions, liabilities, damages, costs, and expenses (including attorney's fees) incurred by Zebracorp, its Affiliates, customers, or contractors due to infringement or alleged infringement of third-party IPR by the products/deliverables sold or licensed.
content.expert_insight: This example clause is a strong starting point for Zebracorp, covering defense, a broad range of costs, and extending protection to affiliates, customers, and contractors.
content.justification: Provides a direct example of an IPR indemnity clause.
content.implication_company: This clause provides comprehensive protection for Zebracorp and its ecosystem.
content.implication_supplier: This clause imposes a broad and significant obligation on the supplier, covering defense and a wide array of potential costs for Zebracorp and related parties.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly provides an example clause.
content.text: “The [Supplier] shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless [Zebracorp] and its Affiliates at its own expense from and against any claims, actions, liabilities, damages, costs and expenses (including but not limited to attorney's fees and costs) incurred by the [Zebracorp], its Affiliates or their respective customers and contractors as a result of infringement or alleged infringement of any intellectual property rights of any third parties by any [products and deliverable sold or licensed hereunder.”

content.verbatim_text: The scope of the indemnity should cover at the minimum patents, copyrights and trademarks. ... Vendors will for obvious reasons seek to exclude patents from the scope of indemnity but such an exclusion should be categorically rejected.
content.plain_text: The indemnity must cover at least patents, copyrights, and trademarks. Any attempt by vendors to exclude patents from the scope of indemnity must be categorically rejected.
content.expert_insight: Patents are a primary source of litigation in IT; their exclusion would severely weaken Zebracorp's protection. This is a non-negotiable point for critical risk mitigation.
content.conditions: When negotiating the scope of IPR indemnity.
content.justification: Patents are a major source of IP litigation in the IT industry, making their inclusion essential for Zebracorp's protection.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure comprehensive IP protection, especially for patents, to mitigate significant litigation risks.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must accept liability for patent infringement, which is a common and high-risk area in the IT industry.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states the minimum coverage and a non-negotiable stance on patent exclusion.
content.text: The scope of the indemnity should cover at the minimum patents, copyrights and trademarks. ... Vendors will for obvious reasons seek to exclude patents from the scope of indemnity but such an exclusion should be categorically rejected.

content.verbatim_text: The indemnitees should include the contracting entity of Zebracorp and its Affiliates, as applicable. The Zebracorp Affiliates are required to be mentioned since it may be an Zebracorp Affiliate that has placed the order or it could also be that the Affiliate becomes involved in the distribution of the supplier products/services in the country where the infringement claim was made.
content.plain_text: The indemnity should explicitly include Zebracorp's contracting entity and its Affiliates as indemnitees, as Affiliates may place orders or be involved in product distribution, making them potential targets of infringement claims.
content.expert_insight: Broadening the indemnitee scope protects the entire corporate structure involved in the product's lifecycle, preventing gaps in coverage.
content.conditions: When defining the beneficiaries of the IPR indemnity.
content.justification: Zebracorp's corporate structure and distribution channels mean Affiliates can also incur damages from IPR infringement.
content.implication_company: Ensures that all relevant Zebracorp entities are protected under the indemnity.
content.implication_supplier: Expands the scope of parties for whom the supplier must provide indemnity, increasing potential liability.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states who should be included as indemnitees and provides a justification.
content.text: The indemnitees should include the contracting entity of Zebracorp and its Affiliates, as applicable. The Zebracorp Affiliates are required to be mentioned since it may be an Zebracorp Affiliate that has placed the order or it could also be that the Affiliate becomes involved in the distribution of the supplier products/services in the country where the infringement claim was made.

content.verbatim_text: Most vendors will seek to limit the obligation to compensate attorneys/legal fees to reasonable fees only. Whilst this may be seem a reasonable proposition, it should not be readily accepted. Attorneys/legal fees can be substantial, and having an obligation to prove that these fees are reasonable can materially impair our ability to seek compensation for such costs. Instead of agreeing to ‘reasonable attorneys fees’, we should consider countering with in e.g. ‘necessarily incurred attorneys fees’. As a fallback we can agree to inserting a ‘reasonable’ qualifier.
content.plain_text: Do not readily accept vendor proposals to limit attorney/legal fees to 'reasonable fees only,' as proving reasonableness can hinder compensation. Counter with 'necessarily incurred attorneys fees' or, as a fallback, accept a 'reasonable' qualifier.
content.expert_insight: The 'reasonableness' standard introduces an additional burden of proof that can be costly and difficult to meet, potentially leaving Zebracorp undercompensated for actual legal expenses. 'Necessarily incurred' is a more favorable standard.
content.conditions: When negotiating compensation for attorney/legal fees within the indemnity.
content.justification: Proving 'reasonable' fees can be challenging and costly, potentially reducing Zebracorp's ability to recover actual legal expenses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp aims to recover full legal costs without additional litigation over 'reasonableness'.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may face higher legal fee compensation obligations if 'necessarily incurred' or no qualifier is accepted.
content.source_insight: The text provides specific advice and rationale for negotiating legal fees.
content.text: Most vendors will seek to limit the obligation to compensate attorneys/legal fees to reasonable fees only. Whilst this may be seem a reasonable proposition, it should not be readily accepted. Attorneys/legal fees can be substantial, and having an obligation to prove that these fees are reasonable can materially impair our ability to seek compensation for such costs. Instead of agreeing to ‘reasonable attorneys fees’, we should consider countering with in e.g. ‘necessarily incurred attorneys fees’. As a fallback we can agree to inserting a ‘reasonable’ qualifier.

content.verbatim_text: A number of vendors will seek to limit the indemnity to damages that are ‘finally awarded’ by in e.g. saying that they will indemnify against any “damages finally awarded by a court of competent jurisdiction against [Zebracorp]”. This qualifier changes the scope of the indemnity dramatically as it limits the indemnity solely to those damages that a court would order Zebracorp to pay to the third party claimant. Essentially the claim would not only have to be made by the third party claimant but subsequently litigated, and the judgment must be final before the vendor would incur any obligation to compensate us for the damages we have incurred. This leaves a substantial amount of damages and costs out of the indemnity and is only rarely acceptable. This is because most IP lawsuits hardly ever reach a point of final court order but are settled. Zebracorp is also likely to incur costs and damages as a result of in e.g. obtaining replacement products, experiencing production stoppages and order cancellations, customer claims and attorneys fees.
content.plain_text: Do not accept clauses limiting indemnity to 'finally awarded' damages, as this dramatically narrows the scope to only court-ordered payments after final judgment, excluding significant costs from settlements, replacement products, production stoppages, and legal fees. This is rarely acceptable because most IP lawsuits settle before a final court order.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical negotiation point. Limiting indemnity to 'finally awarded' damages severely undermines Zebracorp's protection, as it ignores the vast majority of real-world costs associated with IP claims, which are often settled. It also shifts litigation risk and financial burden onto Zebracorp.
content.conditions: When negotiating the scope of damages covered by the indemnity.
content.justification: Most IP lawsuits settle, and Zebracorp incurs significant costs beyond court-ordered damages, which 'finally awarded' excludes.
content.implication_company: Accepting this limitation would leave Zebracorp exposed to substantial unrecoverable costs and damages from IP claims.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers seek this limitation to reduce their financial exposure by only covering adjudicated damages, shifting settlement costs and other business impacts to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text provides strong guidance and detailed justification against accepting 'finally awarded' damages.
content.text: A number of vendors will seek to limit the indemnity to damages that are ‘finally awarded’ by in e.g. saying that they will indemnify against any “damages finally awarded by a court of competent jurisdiction against [Zebracorp]”. This qualifier changes the scope of the indemnity dramatically as it limits the indemnity solely to those damages that a court would order Zebracorp to pay to the third party claimant. Essentially the claim would not only have to be made by the third party claimant but subsequently litigated, and the judgment must be final before the vendor would incur any obligation to compensate us for the damages we have incurred. This leaves a substantial amount of damages and costs out of the indemnity and is only rarely acceptable. This is because most IP lawsuits hardly ever reach a point of final court order but are settled. Zebracorp is also likely to incur costs and damages as a result of in e.g. obtaining replacement products, experiencing production stoppages and order cancellations, customer claims and attorneys fees.

content.verbatim_text: If we do exceptionally agree to limit the indemnity to finally awarded damages we should specify that this final award can be either through arbitration or local court and that the supplier will also pay for any sums agreed in a settlement. Also we should insert a provision to specify the supplier’s obligations and liability in the event there is an injunction (i.e. a court order prohibiting ZEBRACORP or its customers from using or distributing the allegedly infringing products/services). Also we should seek to secure a right to be compensated for our legal fees.
content.plain_text: If, exceptionally, indemnity is limited to 'finally awarded' damages, ensure it includes awards from arbitration or local courts, and covers settlement sums. Additionally, include provisions for supplier obligations and liability in case of an injunction, and secure compensation for Zebracorp's legal fees.
content.expert_insight: These are crucial fallback protections if the 'finally awarded' limitation cannot be avoided. Covering settlements, injunctions, and legal fees helps mitigate the severe risks introduced by such a limitation.
content.conditions: If Zebracorp exceptionally agrees to limit indemnity to 'finally awarded' damages.
content.justification: These measures are necessary to mitigate the substantial risks and costs Zebracorp would otherwise incur if indemnity is limited to 'finally awarded' damages.
content.implication_company: These provisions offer crucial safeguards, ensuring some recovery even with a highly restrictive indemnity clause.
content.implication_supplier: Even with a 'finally awarded' limitation, suppliers would still be liable for settlements, injunction-related costs, and Zebracorp's legal fees under these conditions.
content.source_insight: The text provides specific instructions for mitigating risks when a difficult concession is made.
content.text: If we do exceptionally agree to limit the indemnity to finally awarded damages we should specify that this final award can be either through arbitration or local court and that the supplier will also pay for any sums agreed in a settlement. Also we should insert a provision to specify the supplier’s obligations and liability in the event there is an injunction (i.e. a court order prohibiting ZEBRACORP or its customers from using or distributing the allegedly infringing products/services). Also we should seek to secure a right to be compensated for our legal fees.

content.verbatim_text: The indemnity should apply to claims made in any country/jurisdiction in the world. However, it may be acceptable to agree that the indemnity will not apply in countries that do not provide adequate protection of intellectual property rights. ... Any other geographic limitations should be carefully reviewed and discussed with Legal & Compliance.
content.plain_text: The indemnity should ideally cover claims globally. It may be acceptable to exclude countries lacking adequate IP protection (e.g., non-Paris Convention parties). All other geographic limitations must be carefully reviewed with Legal & Compliance.
content.expert_insight: Global coverage is ideal for Zebracorp's international operations. Any geographic carve-outs must be strategic and limited to truly high-risk, low-protection jurisdictions, and always vetted by legal experts.
content.conditions: When defining the geographic scope of the indemnity.
content.justification: Zebracorp operates globally, requiring worldwide protection. Excluding countries with poor IP protection can be a reasonable compromise.
content.implication_company: Ensures broad protection for Zebracorp's global business, with a pragmatic approach to high-risk jurisdictions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers face worldwide liability unless specific, justified geographic exclusions are negotiated.
content.source_insight: The text provides clear guidance on geographic scope and necessary consultations.
content.text: The indemnity should apply to claims made in any country/jurisdiction in the world. However, it may be acceptable to agree that the indemnity will not apply in countries that do not provide adequate protection of intellectual property rights. ... Any other geographic limitations should be carefully reviewed and discussed with Legal & Compliance.

content.verbatim_text: The deletion of word “alleged” can be accepted if it is otherwise clear from the context that any infringement claim alone will trigger the indemnity.
content.plain_text: The word 'alleged' can be removed from 'alleged infringement' if the contract clearly states that an infringement claim, even if not proven, triggers the indemnity.
content.expert_insight: This concession is acceptable only if the underlying intent of triggering indemnity upon a claim (not just proven infringement) is preserved through other clear contractual language.
content.conditions: If a vendor requests to delete 'alleged' from 'alleged infringement' in the indemnity clause.
content.justification: The key is ensuring the indemnity is triggered by the claim itself, not just a final finding of infringement.
content.implication_company: Acceptable if the indemnity's triggering event remains a claim, not a proven infringement.
content.implication_supplier: Slightly reduces the scope if 'alleged' is removed without clear contextual support for claims-based triggering.
content.source_insight: The text provides a condition for accepting a specific wording change.
content.text: The deletion of word “alleged” can be accepted if it is otherwise clear from the context that any infringement claim alone will trigger the indemnity.

content.verbatim_text: It is not recommended to delete the word “indemnify” and leave the term “hold harmless”. This is because in some countries, the term “hold harmless” does not have a well established legal meaning.
content.plain_text: Do not delete 'indemnify' while retaining 'hold harmless,' as 'hold harmless' lacks a well-established legal meaning in some jurisdictions, potentially weakening the clause.
content.expert_insight: The term 'indemnify' carries a clear legal obligation to compensate. Relying solely on 'hold harmless' introduces legal uncertainty and risk in jurisdictions where its meaning is ambiguous.
content.conditions: When negotiating the terms 'indemnify' and 'hold harmless'.
content.justification: The term 'hold harmless' has inconsistent legal meaning across jurisdictions, potentially weakening Zebracorp's protection.
content.implication_company: Deleting 'indemnify' could create legal ambiguity and weaken Zebracorp's ability to recover losses.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might seek this change to introduce ambiguity and potentially limit their liability, but it's not recommended for Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text provides a strong recommendation and justification against a specific wording change.
content.text: It is not recommended to delete the word “indemnify” and leave the term “hold harmless”. This is because in some countries, the term “hold harmless” does not have a well established legal meaning.

content.verbatim_text: However, we should be cautious to accept wording where we agree that the products must directly infringe third party intellectual property rights. This addition would imply that the product must itself infringe at the moment of delivery and would remove the supplier’s liability for any claims that are caused by the combination of the supplier product to our product.
content.plain_text: Be cautious about accepting language that requires products to 'directly infringe' third-party IPR, as this could remove supplier liability for combination claims (where the supplier's product infringes when combined with Zebracorp's product).
content.expert_insight: The 'directly infringe' qualifier significantly narrows supplier liability, excluding common scenarios where infringement arises from the integration of components. This is a critical point to resist to maintain comprehensive coverage.
content.conditions: When reviewing language regarding the nature of infringement (e.g., 'directly infringe').
content.justification: This wording limits supplier liability to direct infringement at delivery, excluding critical 'combination claims' where infringement arises from product integration.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp would bear the risk for infringement claims arising from combining the supplier's product with its own, even if the supplier's product is a contributing factor.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers seek this to limit their liability to standalone product infringement, avoiding responsibility for combination claims.
content.source_insight: The text provides a caution and explanation regarding specific wording.
content.text: However, we should be cautious to accept wording where we agree that the products must directly infringe third party intellectual property rights. This addition would imply that the product must itself infringe at the moment of delivery and would remove the supplier’s liability for any claims that are caused by the combination of the supplier product to our product.

content.verbatim_text: Sophisticated vendors may attempt to limit their liability to reasonable royalties that are based upon revenue derived by the vendor from Zebracorp from sales or license of the infringing product. ... This is generally not acceptable as this type of a limitation would rule out the vendor’s liability for any royalties that our end customer ends up paying to the third party claimant. It would also exclude the vendor’s liability for any royalties that are calculated on a per use basis or calculated in e.g. by the revenues made by the end user. In the event this request to exclude per-use royalties from the scope of the indemnity cannot be negotiated away, it is often preferable to agree to a monetary liability cap instead of agreeing to such request.
content.plain_text: Do not accept vendor attempts to limit liability to royalties based solely on vendor revenue from Zebracorp, as this excludes royalties paid by end customers or those calculated on a per-use/end-user revenue basis. If this cannot be negotiated away, a monetary liability cap is preferable.
content.expert_insight: This limitation severely restricts the supplier's financial responsibility to a fraction of the actual damages Zebracorp or its customers might incur, shifting a massive financial burden to Zebracorp. It's a critical point to resist, with a monetary cap being a lesser evil if no other option exists.
content.conditions: When vendors attempt to limit IPR indemnity liability to specific royalty calculations.
content.justification: This limitation would unfairly restrict supplier liability, leaving Zebracorp or its end customers exposed to significant uncompensated royalty costs.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp would be responsible for substantial royalty payments to third parties that are not covered by the supplier's indemnity.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers attempt to minimize their financial exposure by linking liability to their direct revenue from Zebracorp, but this is generally unacceptable.
content.source_insight: The text provides strong guidance and justification against a specific liability limitation.
content.text: Sophisticated vendors may attempt to limit their liability to reasonable royalties that are based upon revenue derived by the vendor from Zebracorp from sales or license of the infringing product. ... This is generally not acceptable as this type of a limitation would rule out the vendor’s liability for any royalties that our end customer ends up paying to the third party claimant. It would also exclude the vendor’s liability for any royalties that are calculated on a per use basis or calculated in e.g. by the revenues made by the end user. In the event this request to exclude per-use royalties from the scope of the indemnity cannot be negotiated away, it is often preferable to agree to a monetary liability cap instead of agreeing to such request.

content.verbatim_text: It is worth noting that the duty to defend and duty to indemnify are separate and distinct obligations, and because the duty to defend and the duty to indemnify are distinct obligations, the contract may impose a duty to defend the underlying claim even in the absence of a duty to indemnify. In fact, if the supplier is successful in defending the third party IPR infringement claim, there may be little or no damages for Zebracorp to recover from the supplier.
content.plain_text: The duties to defend and indemnify are distinct; a contract can mandate defense even without an indemnity obligation. If the supplier successfully defends an IPR claim, Zebracorp may recover minimal or no damages.
content.expert_insight: Understanding this separation is key. A supplier might defend a claim, but if no damages are ultimately awarded or settled, the indemnity obligation might not be triggered, or the amount recovered could be small.
content.justification: Explains the distinction between duty to defend and duty to indemnify and their potential outcomes.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp benefits from a defense, even if direct damages are not ultimately recovered, as it avoids the burden of litigation.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that fulfilling the duty to defend might prevent indemnity obligations from arising.
content.source_insight: The text provides clarifying information on legal duties.
content.text: It is worth noting that the duty to defend and duty to indemnify are separate and distinct obligations, and because the duty to defend and the duty to indemnify are distinct obligations, the contract may impose a duty to defend the underlying claim even in the absence of a duty to indemnify. In fact, if the supplier is successful in defending the third party IPR infringement claim, there may be little or no damages for Zebracorp to recover from the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: We should be careful in granting the supplier’s a right to defend the claim. ... This means that we should not offer the supplier unconditional and sole right and authority to defend the claims. Further, in those rare occasions where the supplier’s liability for IPR is capped or limtied, we obviously cannot allow the supplier to freely defend the case.
content.plain_text: Be cautious when granting the supplier the right to defend a claim; do not offer unconditional and sole defense authority, especially if the supplier's IPR liability is capped or limited.
content.expert_insight: Granting sole defense rights when Zebracorp's customers are targets or when supplier liability is capped creates a conflict of interest. Zebracorp needs control or significant oversight to protect its broader business interests and ensure an adequate defense.

content.justification: Granting unconditional defense rights can lead to conflicts of interest, especially if Zebracorp's customers are targets or if the supplier's liability is capped.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs to retain sufficient control over defense to protect its business interests, customers, and ensure adequate representation, especially when its own liability is at stake.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may seek full control of defense to manage costs, but this is restricted by Zebracorp's need to protect its broader interests.

content.verbatim_text: “If a claim, alleging infringement is made, [Supplier] shall have the option at its expense, and without prejudice to its indemnity obligation, to (1) modify the [Product] to avoid the alleged infringement, while at the same time maintaining compliance of the [Products] and other requirements of this Agreement (“Design-Around”), or (2) obtain for [Buyer] and/or its respective customers, at no additional cost, a license to continue using and exploiting the [Products] in accordance with this Agreement free of any liability or restriction (“Substitution”).”
content.plain_text: An example clause for ancillary obligations states that if an infringement claim is made, the Supplier has the option, at its expense and without affecting its indemnity obligation, to either (1) 'Design-Around' by modifying the product to avoid infringement while maintaining compliance, or (2) 'Substitution' by obtaining a license for the Buyer and/or its customers to continue using the products without additional cost or liability.
content.expert_insight: This clause provides the supplier with proactive options to resolve infringement issues, which is beneficial for both parties as it aims to minimize disruption and ongoing liability. The 'without prejudice' language is critical.
content.justification: Provides an example of ancillary obligations/options in an IPR indemnity.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp benefits from the supplier's proactive options to resolve infringement, minimizing business disruption.
content.implication_supplier: These options provide the supplier with ways to mitigate ongoing infringement issues and manage their indemnity obligations.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly provides an example clause for ancillary obligations.
content.text: “If a claim, alleging infringement is made, [Supplier] shall have the option at its expense, and without prejudice to its indemnity obligation, to (1) modify the [Product] to avoid the alleged infringement, while at the same time maintaining compliance of the [Products] and other requirements of this Agreement (“Design-Around”), or (2) obtain for [Buyer] and/or its respective customers, at no additional cost, a license to continue using and exploiting the [Products] in accordance with this Agreement free of any liability or restriction (“Substitution”).”

content.verbatim_text: We should be careful when agreeing to accept this type of refund. In direct procurement contracts ZEBRACORP is likely to have sold and distributed the infringing products further to our end customers, and returning the products or requiring the end customer to cease further use of the product may cause irreparable damage and costs that far exceeds the potential royalties payable for the alleged infringement, or in worst case it may be impossible to comply with such request. Instead of agreeing to return the products or cease further use of the products, we should in such cases offer to agree to cease all further distribution and resale of the infringing products. When agreeing to this third option, we should also add language saying that this refund/right to cease further distribution of products is only available to the supplier in the event the two first options (i.e. the Design-Around and Substitution) are not reasonably feasible or achievable, and provided that we are given reasonable time to cease such further distribution.
content.plain_text: Be cautious about accepting a supplier's third option to refund the purchase price in exchange for product return or cessation of use, as this can cause irreparable damage and costs for Zebracorp and its customers. Instead, offer to cease further distribution and resale. If this refund option is accepted, ensure it's only available if Design-Around and Substitution are not feasible, and Zebracorp is given reasonable time to cease distribution.
content.expert_insight: The refund option can be highly detrimental to Zebracorp's business and customer relationships. It's crucial to prioritize solutions that maintain business continuity (Design-Around, Substitution) and to severely restrict the refund option, ensuring Zebracorp's ability to manage its supply chain and customer commitments.
content.conditions: When negotiating a supplier's option to refund infringing products.
content.justification: Returning products or ceasing customer use can cause severe business disruption and costs for Zebracorp that far exceed the refund value.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from significant business disruption, customer claims, and financial losses associated with product returns or forced cessation of use.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will have limited ability to force product returns or cessation of use, pushing them towards design-around or licensing solutions.
content.source_insight: The text provides detailed guidance and justification for negotiating the refund option.
content.text: We should be careful when agreeing to accept this type of refund. In direct procurement contracts ZEBRACORP is likely to have sold and distributed the infringing products further to our end customers, and returning the products or requiring the end customer to cease further use of the product may cause irreparable damage and costs that far exceeds the potential royalties payable for the alleged infringement, or in worst case it may be impossible to comply with such request. Instead of agreeing to return the products or cease further use of the products, we should in such cases offer to agree to cease all further distribution and resale of the infringing products. When agreeing to this third option, we should also add language saying that this refund/right to cease further distribution of products is only available to the supplier in the event the two first options (i.e. the Design-Around and Substitution) are not reasonably feasible or achievable, and provided that we are given reasonable time to cease such further distribution.

content.verbatim_text: It is important to mention that the supplier is not relieved from its obligation to indemnify Zebracorp by simply picking one of the above three options. This is because Zebracorp is likely to have already incurred damages and costs even if the supplier proves successful in implementing in e.g. a design-around that removes the infringement. This is achieved by including the word: “…without prejudice to its indemnity obligation…” in the above example provision.
content.plain_text: The supplier's indemnity obligation is not relieved by choosing one of the ancillary options (Design-Around, Substitution, or Refund), as Zebracorp may have already incurred damages. This is ensured by including '…without prejudice to its indemnity obligation…' in the clause.
content.expert_insight: This 'without prejudice' clause is vital. It ensures that the supplier's proactive solutions do not negate their responsibility for damages already incurred by Zebracorp due to the initial infringement.
content.conditions: When drafting or reviewing ancillary obligation clauses.
content.justification: Zebracorp will incur damages and costs regardless of the supplier's chosen resolution option, so the indemnity obligation must remain.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp can still claim for damages incurred prior to or during the implementation of a resolution option.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must understand that resolving the infringement does not absolve them of liability for past damages.
content.source_insight: The text provides a critical point and specific wording for ancillary obligations.
content.text: It is important to mention that the supplier is not relieved from its obligation to indemnify Zebracorp by simply picking one of the above three options. This is because Zebracorp is likely to have already incurred damages and costs even if the supplier proves successful in implementing in e.g. a design-around that removes the infringement. This is achieved by including the word: “…without prejudice to its indemnity obligation…” in the above example provision.

content.verbatim_text: “[Zebracorp] shall (i) notify the [Supplier] of the allegation in writing and (ii) upon [Supplier]’s confirmation to defend, provide the Supplier with the sole authority to defend such claim, provided that (a) [Zebracorp] shall have the right to have access to all necessary information to defend itself against the allegation as well as the right to select its own counsel to participate in any actions at the expense of the [Supplier] (b) the [Supplier]shall at all times takes into account the business interests of [Zebracorp], its Affiliates and their customers in defending and settling such claim, and (c) the [Supplier] shall obtain the prior written approval of [Zebracorp], which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, before entering into any settlement of such claim or ceasing to defend against such claim, [Zebracorp] shall cooperate with the [Supplier], at the expense of the Licensor, in the defensive actions, as reasonably requested by the [Supplier].”
content.plain_text: An example clause for indemnification procedure states that Zebracorp must (i) notify the Supplier in writing of an allegation and (ii) grant the Supplier sole defense authority upon confirmation to defend, provided Zebracorp retains access to information, can select its own counsel at Supplier's expense, the Supplier considers Zebracorp's business interests in defense/settlement, and obtains Zebracorp's prior written approval (not unreasonably withheld) for settlement or ceasing defense. Zebracorp will cooperate with the Supplier, at the Licensor's expense, as reasonably requested.
content.expert_insight: This clause balances the supplier's right to defend with Zebracorp's need to protect its interests, particularly through access to information, participation rights, and settlement approval. The conditions placed on the supplier's 'sole authority' are crucial.
content.justification: Provides an example of a Zebracorp-preferred indemnification procedure clause.
content.implication_company: This clause ensures Zebracorp maintains control and oversight even when the supplier defends, protecting its broader business interests.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier gains defense authority but is constrained by Zebracorp's rights, interests, and approval requirements.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly provides an example clause for indemnification procedure.
content.text: “[Zebracorp] shall (i) notify the [Supplier] of the allegation in writing and (ii) upon [Supplier]’s confirmation to defend, provide the Supplier with the sole authority to defend such claim, provided that (a) [Zebracorp] shall have the right to have access to all necessary information to defend itself against the allegation as well as the right to select its own counsel to participate in any actions at the expense of the [Supplier] (b) the [Supplier]shall at all times takes into account the business interests of [Zebracorp], its Affiliates and their customers in defending and settling such claim, and (c) the [Supplier] shall obtain the prior written approval of [Zebracorp], which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, before entering into any settlement of such claim or ceasing to defend against such claim, [Zebracorp] shall cooperate with the [Supplier], at the expense of the Licensor, in the defensive actions, as reasonably requested by the [Supplier].”

content.verbatim_text: However, we should not agree to wording such as “immediately” or “promptly” as any inadvertent delay may give the supplier a case for trying to walk away from the entire indemnity obligation. In the event the supplier is adamant about using the words “promptly” or “immediately”, we should consider adding in e.g. the following clarifying language: “failure by the [buyer] to inform the [supplier] of any claim in a timely manner will only affect the obligations of the [supplier] if and to the extent the [supplier] is directly prejudiced as a result of such delay”.
content.plain_text: Do not agree to 'immediately' or 'promptly' for notification of infringement claims, as inadvertent delays could allow the supplier to escape indemnity. If these terms are insisted upon, add clarifying language: 'failure by the [buyer] to inform the [supplier] of any claim in a timely manner will only affect the obligations of the [supplier] if and to the extent the [supplier] is directly prejudiced as a result of such delay'.
content.expert_insight: Strict notification timelines like 'immediately' create a high risk of technical breach for Zebracorp, potentially voiding the indemnity. The 'prejudice' qualifier is a vital safeguard, ensuring that a minor delay doesn't automatically release the supplier from their core obligation.
content.conditions: When negotiating the timeframe for notifying the supplier of an infringement claim.
content.justification: Strict notification terms like 'immediately' or 'promptly' create a high risk of technical breach for Zebracorp, potentially allowing the supplier to avoid indemnity.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from losing indemnity coverage due to minor or inadvertent delays in notification.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers cannot use minor notification delays as an automatic escape clause unless they can prove direct prejudice.
content.source_insight: The text provides strong guidance and specific language for notification clauses.
content.text: However, we should not agree to wording such as “immediately” or “promptly” as any inadvertent delay may give the supplier a case for trying to walk away from the entire indemnity obligation. In the event the supplier is adamant about using the words “promptly” or “immediately”, we should consider adding in e.g. the following clarifying language: “failure by the [buyer] to inform the [supplier] of any claim in a timely manner will only affect the obligations of the [supplier] if and to the extent the [supplier] is directly prejudiced as a result of such delay”.

content.verbatim_text: Note however that we should not allow the supplier to take control over the defense/settlement of the claim in the event we agree to cap the supplier’s liability for the claims. Please consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team on how to revise the indemnity and defense provisions in such case.
content.plain_text: Do not allow the supplier to control the defense or settlement of a claim if the supplier's liability for that claim is capped. Consult Legal & Compliance for revisions in such cases.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental conflict of interest. A supplier with capped liability has less incentive to vigorously defend or settle favorably for Zebracorp, as their maximum exposure is fixed. Zebracorp must retain control to protect its uncapped exposure.
content.conditions: If the supplier's liability for IPR claims is capped.
content.justification: A supplier with capped liability has a reduced incentive to defend vigorously or settle favorably, creating a conflict of interest that could harm Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must retain control to protect its uncapped exposure and ensure the best outcome for the claim.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers with capped liability will not be granted full control over defense or settlement, limiting their ability to manage costs independently.
content.source_insight: The text provides a critical rule and instruction for a specific scenario.
content.text: Note however that we should not allow the supplier to take control over the defense/settlement of the claim in the event we agree to cap the supplier’s liability for the claims. Please consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team on how to revise the indemnity and defense provisions in such case.

content.verbatim_text: ZEBRACORP’s duty to cooperate in defending the claim should be subject to such cooperation being reasonable. We would also expect to be compensated for the costs that we incur from providing such assistance. If this point becomes contentious, we can agree to cooperate and assist at our own cost so long as our cooperation obligation is limited to whatever is ‘reasonably’ required by the supplier.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's duty to cooperate in defending a claim should be reasonable, and Zebracorp should be compensated for its cooperation costs. If contentious, Zebracorp can agree to cooperate at its own cost, provided the obligation is limited to what is 'reasonably' required by the supplier.
content.expert_insight: Zebracorp should not bear uncompensated costs for assisting the supplier's defense. The 'reasonable' qualifier is key to preventing excessive demands. The fallback position ensures some level of cooperation while limiting Zebracorp's financial burden.
content.conditions: When defining Zebracorp's duty to cooperate in defense.
content.justification: Zebracorp should not incur uncompensated costs for assisting the supplier's defense, and the scope of cooperation should be reasonable.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp is compensated for its efforts in assisting defense or limits its financial outlay for cooperation.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may need to compensate Zebracorp for cooperation or accept a limited scope of uncompensated assistance.
content.source_insight: The text provides guidance on cooperation duties and cost compensation.
content.text: ZEBRACORP’s duty to cooperate in defending the claim should be subject to such cooperation being reasonable. We would also expect to be compensated for the costs that we incur from providing such assistance. If this point becomes contentious, we can agree to cooperate and assist at our own cost so long as our cooperation obligation is limited to whatever is ‘reasonably’ required by the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: “The [Supplier] will have no obligation to defend or indemnify Buyer under this [Clause] if and to the extent: i.) the [Purchaser] or any third party authorized by the [Purchaser] has altered the [Products] without the [Supplier]’s consent and the alleged infringement would not have occurred but for this alteration; ii.) the [Purchaser] or any third party authorized by the [Purchaser] has combined the [Products] with any other products or elements not furnished by the [Supplier] without the [Supplier]’s consent, and the alleged infringement would not have occurred but for this combination and the [Product] itself is not infringing; or iii.) the [Products] were designed or manufactured in accordance with the [Purchaser]’s written detailed design and specifications mandated by the [Purchaser] without freedom of design for the [Supplier] and the alleged infringement would not have occurred but for these written detailed designs and specifications”.
content.plain_text: An example carve-out clause states that the Supplier has no indemnity obligation if: (i) the Purchaser or an authorized third party altered products without Supplier's consent, and the infringement wouldn't have occurred otherwise; (ii) the Purchaser or an authorized third party combined products with non-supplied elements without Supplier's consent, the infringement wouldn't have occurred otherwise, and the product itself isn't infringing; or (iii) products were designed to Purchaser's mandated specifications without Supplier's design freedom, and the infringement wouldn't have occurred otherwise.
content.expert_insight: This example outlines typical carve-outs that shift liability back to the buyer for actions outside the supplier's control or design responsibility. The 'but for' causation is a key element for these exclusions.
content.justification: Provides an example of a typical carve-out clause for IPR indemnity.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs to be aware that its own actions (unauthorized modifications, combinations, or mandated designs) can negate supplier indemnity.
content.implication_supplier: These carve-outs protect suppliers from liability when infringement is caused by the buyer's actions or specific instructions.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly provides an example of a carve-out clause.
content.text: “The [Supplier] will have no obligation to defend or indemnify Buyer under this [Clause] if and to the extent: i.) the [Purchaser] or any third party authorized by the [Purchaser] has altered the [Products] without the [Supplier]’s consent and the alleged infringement would not have occurred but for this alteration; ii.) the [Purchaser] or any third party authorized by the [Purchaser] has combined the [Products] with any other products or elements not furnished by the [Supplier] without the [Supplier]’s consent, and the alleged infringement would not have occurred but for this combination and the [Product] itself is not infringing; or iii.) the [Products] were designed or manufactured in accordance with the [Purchaser]’s written detailed design and specifications mandated by the [Purchaser] without freedom of design for the [Supplier] and the alleged infringement would not have occurred but for these written detailed designs and specifications”.

content.verbatim_text: Care should be taken in negotiating these carve-outs. In each case it is worth mentioning specifically that the supplier will not benefit from the exclusion if the infringement would not have occurred without the modification or combination made by buyer or without buyer specification. As for the carve-out on Zebracorp provided specifications, it is important to stress that the specifications have to be mandated by Zebracorp without any freedom of design for the supplier in order for the supplier to be able to shift the liability for IP infringement to Zebracorp. In most cases, Zebracorp will have to rely on the expertise of the supplier in building and designing the product, and the mere fact that Zebracorp provides certain requirements/specifications for the products it purchases should not transfer the risk of IP infringements over to Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Negotiate carve-outs carefully, ensuring the supplier only benefits from an exclusion if the infringement would not have occurred 'but for' the buyer's modification, combination, or mandated specification. For Zebracorp-provided specifications, liability shifts only if specifications were mandated without supplier design freedom, as Zebracorp typically relies on supplier expertise.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes the 'but for' causation and the importance of supplier design freedom. Zebracorp should not accept liability for infringement merely because it provided requirements, as the supplier is the expert designing the product.
content.conditions: When negotiating carve-outs for IPR indemnity.
content.justification: Ensures that carve-outs are applied fairly and only when Zebracorp's actions are the direct cause of infringement, rather than the supplier's design or product.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from assuming liability for infringement when it has relied on supplier expertise or when its actions were not the sole cause.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must demonstrate direct causation from Zebracorp's actions or truly mandated specifications to benefit from carve-outs.
content.source_insight: The text provides detailed guidance and justification for negotiating carve-outs.

In most cases, Zebracorp will have to rely on the expertise of the supplier in building and designing the product, and the mere fact that Zebracorp provides certain requirements/specifications for the products it purchases should not transfer the risk of IP infringements over to Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: Another common carve-out proposed by sophisticated vendors seeks to exclude ‘all claims asserted by a company, which exercises control over Zebracorp or which is controlled by Zebracorp’. This carve out essentially prevents Zebracorp from taking advantage of the indemnity when the third party making the infringement claim is in fact not a third party but an affiliated company of Zebracorp. Such carve-outs are generally acceptable.
content.plain_text: Carve-outs excluding claims from Zebracorp's affiliated companies (i.e., not true third parties) are generally acceptable.
content.expert_insight: This is a reasonable exclusion, as indemnities are typically meant to protect against external third-party claims, not internal corporate disputes.

content.justification: Indemnities are designed for third-party claims, not internal corporate disputes.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should not expect indemnity for claims originating from its own corporate group.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are protected from claims made by Zebracorp's affiliates, which are not considered true third parties.

content.verbatim_text: The suppliers are fairly often likely to represent the viewpoint that Zebracorp should itself indemnify the supplier for any claims that are based on these carve-outs i.e. based on Zebracorp modifications etc. Such indemnities from Zebracorp to supplier should not be taken for granted. We should keep in mind that Zebracorp is not providing any products/services to the supplier against a fee and accordingly should not be expected to provide indemnities to the supplier. The indemnities should be provided by the selling party to the purchasing party.
content.plain_text: Do not readily grant indemnities from Zebracorp to the supplier for claims arising from carve-outs (e.g., Zebracorp modifications). Zebracorp, as the purchasing party not providing products/services for a fee, should not generally be expected to indemnify the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical principle: indemnities flow from the selling party (supplier) to the purchasing party (Zebracorp). Granting a reverse indemnity shifts risk inappropriately and should be strongly resisted unless very specific, limited conditions apply.

content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from assuming undue liability for the supplier's risks.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will find it difficult to obtain indemnities from Zebracorp unless specific, limited exceptions are negotiated.
content.source_insight: The text provides strong guidance and justification against reverse indemnities.

content.verbatim_text: “This section contains i. the [Supplier]’s entire liability and all obligations related to third party intellectual property infringement or misappropriation, and ii. the [Purchaser]’s exclusive remedies against the [Supplier] for such third party intellectual property infringement or misappropriation. These remedies are provided in lieu of all other warranties, whether express, implied or statutory”.
content.plain_text: An example clause for 'Entire Liability and Exclusive Remedies' states that the section defines the Supplier's entire liability and obligations for third-party IP infringement, and the Purchaser's exclusive remedies, replacing all other warranties.

content.verbatim_text: It is not uncommon for the seller to try to limit its liability for IPR infringement claims to any amounts that would have been due as a reasonable royalty based on the price of the seller’s products. ... Whilst the rationale behind such limitations is understandable, the effect of such limitation can put Zebracorp as substantial disadvantage, and these type of limitations should be carefully considered with IPR and/or Legal & Compliance.
content.plain_text: Do not accept seller attempts to limit IPR infringement liability to reasonable royalties based solely on the seller's product price, as this puts Zebracorp at a substantial disadvantage by not accounting for the higher value of Zebracorp's overall product/solution. These limitations require careful consideration with IPR and/or Legal & Compliance teams.
content.expert_insight: This limitation is highly detrimental to Zebracorp, as it caps the supplier's liability at a value far below the potential damages to Zebracorp's integrated solutions. It transfers significant financial risk to Zebracorp and should be strongly resisted.
content.conditions: When sellers attempt to limit IPR liability to royalties based on their product's price.
content.justification: This limitation significantly undervalues the potential damages to Zebracorp's complete product/solution, placing Zebracorp at a substantial disadvantage.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp would bear the financial burden for the difference between the supplier's product value and the value of Zebracorp's integrated solution in an infringement claim.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers seek this to cap their liability at a lower, more predictable amount, but it is generally unacceptable to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text provides strong guidance and justification against a specific liability limitation.
content.text: It is not uncommon for the seller to try to limit its liability for IPR infringement claims to any amounts that would have been due as a reasonable royalty based on the price of the seller’s products. ... Whilst the rationale behind such limitations is understandable, the effect of such limitation can put Zebracorp as substantial disadvantage, and these type of limitations should be carefully considered with IPR and/or Legal & Compliance.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp should be fully indemnified against any assertion that the deliverables provided by the supplier infringe any intellectual property rights of any third party. The indemnity should ideally be unlimited i.e. without monetary caps and without exclusion of indirect damages. ... However, Supplier should not be allowed to enter into any settlement agreement that adversely affects Zebracorp without Zebracorp’s prior written consent.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must be fully indemnified against any third-party IPR infringement claims related to supplier deliverables. Ideally, this indemnity should be unlimited, without monetary caps or exclusion of indirect damages. The Supplier must not settle any claim that adversely affects Zebracorp without Zebracorp's prior written consent.
content.expert_insight: This encapsulates Zebracorp's ideal position: maximum protection, unlimited liability for the supplier, and critical control over settlements to protect its reputation and business interests. These are non-negotiable goals.
content.conditions: When establishing Zebracorp's preferred position for IPR indemnity.
content.justification: Full, unlimited indemnity and settlement control are essential to protect Zebracorp from the significant financial and reputational risks of IPR infringement.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp aims for the highest level of protection, minimizing its financial exposure and maintaining control over critical decisions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will face demands for broad, unlimited liability and will have restricted autonomy in settling claims that impact Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states Zebracorp's preferred position and critical requirements.
content.text: Zebracorp should be fully indemnified against any assertion that the deliverables provided by the supplier infringe any intellectual property rights of any third party. The indemnity should ideally be unlimited i.e. without monetary caps and without exclusion of indirect damages. ... However, Supplier should not be allowed to enter into any settlement agreement that adversely affects Zebracorp without Zebracorp’s prior written consent.

content.verbatim_text: Also Zebracorp should have the right, at its own expense, to actively participate in any suit or proceeding, through its own counsel.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should retain the right to actively participate in any suit or proceeding, using its own counsel, at its own expense.
content.expert_insight: Even if the supplier is defending, Zebracorp's right to participate ensures it can monitor the defense, protect its specific interests (e.g., customer relationships, reputation), and be prepared for potential outcomes.
content.conditions: When defining Zebracorp's rights in IPR infringement suits or proceedings.
content.justification: Active participation allows Zebracorp to protect its own interests, reputation, and customer relationships, even if the supplier is managing the primary defense.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains oversight and influence in legal proceedings that affect its business, even if it bears the cost of its own counsel.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must accommodate Zebracorp's participation in legal proceedings.
content.source_insight: The text states a specific right Zebracorp should have.
content.text: Also Zebracorp should have the right, at its own expense, to actively participate in any suit or proceeding, through its own counsel.

content.verbatim_text: If it becomes apparent through contract negotiations that any material deviations from the standard IPR indemnity must be considered, it is recommended to engage a member of the Legal & Compliance team to determine if such deviations are appropriate and acceptable.
content.plain_text: If material deviations from the standard IPR indemnity arise during negotiations, consult the Legal & Compliance team to assess their appropriateness and acceptability.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial escalation point. Any significant departure from Zebracorp's preferred indemnity position carries substantial risk and requires expert legal review to ensure business protection.
content.justification: Ensures that significant deviations from standard indemnity provisions are properly vetted for risk and acceptability.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must involve legal experts for non-standard indemnity clauses to avoid unforeseen risks.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect that significant deviations they propose will undergo thorough legal review by Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text provides a clear instruction for handling deviations.
content.text: If it becomes apparent through contract negotiations that any material deviations from the standard IPR indemnity must be considered, it is recommended to engage a member of the Legal & Compliance team to determine if such deviations are appropriate and acceptable.
